componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc. Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded.
At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Ms. Gee Lingberg, Vice President. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Anna. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call.Before we begin, I'd like to remind everyone that many of the comments made today are considered to be forward-looking statements under federal
componenttext:
Thanks, Anna. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call.
Before we begin, I'd like to remind everyone that many of the comments made today are considered to be forward-looking statements under federal securities laws. As described in our filings with the SEC, these statements are subject to numerous risks and uncertainties that could cause future results to differ from those expressed, and we're not obligated to publicly update or revise these forward-looking statements.
In addition, on today's call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial information, such as FFO, adjusted EBITDA and comparable hotel results. You can find this information, together with reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP information, in today's earnings press release, in our 8-K filed with the SEC and on our website at hosthotels.com.
With me on the call today is Ed Walter, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Larson, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, Greg will provide -- Ed will provide a brief overview of our fourth quarter and full-year results and then we'll discuss our disposition and redevelopment activity as well as our company's outlook for 2016. Greg will then provide greater detail on our fourth quarter performance by markets. Following their remarks, we will be available to respond to your questions.
[Operator Instructions] And now I'd like to turn the call over to Ed.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gee. Good morning, everyone. Looking back on our performance in 2015, we had an active year and undertook a number of initiatives to capitalize on value enhancing opportunities to better position our company for continued growth and success. We so
componenttext:
Thanks, Gee. Good morning, everyone. Looking back on our performance in 2015, we had an active year and undertook a number of initiatives to capitalize on value enhancing opportunities to better position our company for continued growth and success. We sold more than $1 billion worth of hotels, including 5 of our 9 hotels in Asia as we made good progress on our plans to exit the Asia-Pacific market. We returned $1.3 billion to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases. We invested more than $1 billion in new assets in capital improvements, including the acquisition of the iconic Phoenician Resort and the completion of the major redevelopment of 4 hotels. And finally, we refinanced more than $1.4 billion of debt, reducing our average interest rate by 110 basis points to 3.7%, spending our maturity schedule and further solidifying our industry-leading balance sheet. 
Looking ahead to 2016, we will continue to support a disciplined approach to actively managing our portfolio and efficiently allocating capital. We remained focused on continually improving operational and financial performance to better drive results for our shareholders.
Now, let's review our results for the quarter and the year. Comparable hotel RevPAR for the quarter increased 3.6%, with rate growth of 1.7% and an increase in occupancy of 1.4 percentage points. For the full year, our portfolio achieved an average occupancy of more than 77%, allowing the hotels to drive average rate increase of 3.3%, resulting in an improvement in comparable hotel RevPAR of 3.8%, which equals 4% when adjusted for the impact of the USALI accounting changes.
Adjusted EBITDA was $344 million for the quarter, and $1.409 billion for the year, exceeding consensus estimates and our prior forecast. Our adjusted FFO per diluted share was $0.39 for the fourth quarter and $1.54 for the full year, also exceeding consensus estimates and reflecting a 2.7% increase over 2014.
Even though we were below our RevPAR forecast for the year, adjusted EBITDA was positively affected by the higher-than-expected profits from food and beverage and from our Maui timeshare project, as well as $5 million associated with the write-off of deferred IMF relating to a hotel that converted to a franchise and a reduction in our restricted stock expense.
The quarterly results were driven by an increase in group room nights of more than 2.5%, as Association business grew by more than 6%. Group rate improved by nearly 1.5% as corporate rate growth was up by 4%, which was significantly higher than our year-to-date results. In total, group revenues grew 4%. 
Transient demand increased by 1.5%, although it was primarily in the discount segment as corporate demand was weaker than anticipated, which may reflect the weaker GDP growth the U.S. economy experienced in Q4.
While rate growth in the discount segment was fairly solid, the negative mix shift resulted in average rate increasing just 1% and transient revenue grew just 2.5%. 
Some of the transient weakness was likely due to reduced international travel. While arrivals into the U.S. continued to grow at a healthy pace in the fourth quarter, spending declined slightly would suggest our customer still made the trip, but stayed for fewer days and likely shop less. Our census at international business declined by 5% to 10% in our hotels in the quarter.
The strong group performance translated into strong banquet and catering activity as banquet and catering revenues grew by 6.8% or 5.4% after adjusting for USALI. We experienced above expected catering activity in our Florida hotel and in our larger San Diego and San Francisco assets. Our outlets were also busy as revenues at our restaurants and lounges improved by more than 4.5%. 
Overall, SMB revenues increased 6.1%, or 4.7% after adjusting for USALI, which was one of our best quarters of the year. The higher revenues drove improved margin and our profits exceeded our expectations.
Total revenues for the quarter increased 3.6% and EBITDA margins improved by 55 basis points as a 9% reduction in utility expense and a 15% reduction in insurance costs were partially offset by a 7% increase in property taxes and an increasing ground run in one of our L.A. assets.
Transient demand represented 58% of our total room nights for the full year, an increase just slightly from last year. Transient rate increased 2.8% for the full year, as most segments experienced strong rate growth other than our OTA business. For the full year, transient revenues grew 2.9%. 
Despite starting the year with no additional group room nights on the books, compared to 2014, bookings during the year were solid and group demand improved 1.1% for the year, led by a 3% increase in association business. Overall, group demand represented 37% of our sold rooms and group revenues grew 3.1%. 
F&B revenues grew 5.2% for the full year or 2.5% after adjusting for USALI. The increase resulted from banquet revenue growth of 5.9% for the year and outlook revenue improvement of 3.8%. Reduced construction in our meeting space helped spark a 4.2% USALI adjusted SMB growth in the second half of the year.
Total revenue growth for the year improved by 3.3%, and full year EBITDA margins improved 35 basis points after adjusting for USALI. In 2015, we continued to execute on our strategic plan of reallocating capital out of markets where we expect lower growth or higher capital expenditure requirements. This approach has also enabled us to benefit from the arbitrage between private and public market valuations in the current environment. We had a very active fourth quarter for dispositions with approximately $630 million in sales completed. These included the Sheraton in Perth, the European portfolio, the Novotel in EBITs in Auckland, and the Novotel Queenstown. In addition, as we announced this morning, we closed the sale of the San Diego Mission Valley Marriott, a suburban hotel with 350 rooms, and the Novotel Wellington, a 139-room hotel located in New Zealand, for a combined sales price of almost $100 million. The average RevPAR for these hotels was approximately $116, which is consistent with our primary focus of selling lower RevPAR hotels.
The disposition of non-core assets continues to be a priority. We have an additional $117 million in assets under binding contracts, with closing slated over the next 3 months. We are currently marketing an additional $800 million of assets, with more than 1/3 of those fairly far along the process. We have been pleased with the response to our marketing efforts and remain optimistic that we will continue to complete sales, although there can be no assurances that, that will occur.
As we mentioned last fall, the sales we are targeting to complete will generate a significant amount of taxable income, which will likely result in a special dividend paid at the end of the year. Last year, we suffered significant disruptions from a number of comprehensive renovations that closed parts of several hotels at significant portions of the year. Each of the most impactful renovations: The Logan in Philadelphia, The Camby in Phoenix, the Axiom in San Francisco, and the Houston Airport Marriott, has been or is about to be completed. All the hotels are now open for business and the initial customer reaction has been quite positive. The new rooms started has been well received and the F&B outlets, especially the Urban Farm or The Logan and the at The Camby have generated significant favorable felicity.
Last year, these 4 hotels generated a loss of approximately $4 million. This year, we expect them to contribute between $28 million to $30 million in EBITDA, with additional above average growth expected in 2017.
This year, we are also completing major redevelopments of the Denver Tech marriott, the Hyatt San Francisco Airport and the exhibit Hall of the San Diego Marriott Marquis. While we expect that there will be disruptive impact at the first 2 assets I referenced, we currently anticipate that the San Diego Exhibit Hall project will be completed in midyear and the additional income it will generate will offset the negative impact from the other 2 assets on a full-year basis when compared to 2015.
All 3 hotels should generate above transient improvement in 2017. This morning, based on our closing price from last night, we are trading at the value of 260,000 a key, compared to an estimated replacement cost that exceeds 500,000 a key. Based on the midpoint of our guidance range, which I will discuss shortly, we are trading at 1.5 EBITDA multiple and an 8.5% cap rate. Both measures reflect valuations that are significantly lower than our historical averages, and we believe our stock represents an excellent value opportunity.
As we generate cash flow from operations and asset sales, we believe the best way to deliver the most value for shareholders is to repurchase our undervalued stock. In line with this approach, we purchased a total of $325 million of stock in the fourth quarter, bringing our total for the year to $675 million. When combined with almost $650 million in dividends, we paid over the last 12 months, we have returned approximately $1.3 billion in capital to our shareholders. Assuming 2016 plays out consistently with our expectations, we would continue to execute on our existing share repurchase program and revisit the size of the program later in the year.
The guidance we announced this morning reflects the following: Nationwide supplier growth when net and for likely closures is now approaching the long-term average of 2% for the next couple of years. However, supply growth in the top 20 major markets has accelerated more quickly, and is now likely to exceed 3%. While upper upscale supply in these markets, which is most directly competitive with our portfolio should not exceed 1.5%, strong supply growth in the upscale and midscale segments is driving the overall supply level higher, our portfolio will not be immune to impact from this new supply.
Over the last 3 years, demand growth has averaged more than 3% in the top 20 markets, but consensus forecasts suggest that may moderate slightly in 2016, given the weak economic growth in the fourth quarter and the general lowering of GDP forecast for 2016. We are also watching international travel carefully as it impacts the gateway markets. The combined effect of these 2 factors, which likely influenced the weaker-than-expected fourth quarter room revenue growth in the industry, suggest that demand may not match the flag growth of 2016 progresses.
On a positive side, we had very strong group bookings in the fourth quarter, with the bookings up more than 4.5%. We are starting 2016 with group revenues up more than 6% compared to 2015, which positions us to maintain strong occupancies and drive higher rate of transient business.
In addition, our negotiated rates in those markets have increased more in 2016 than they did in 2015, providing support for transient rate growth. Finally, we have had a solid start in January, reversing the trend we experienced in the fourth quarter as our preliminary RevPAR growth estimate for the month is approximately 3.8%, and that is after the negative impact of about 1% of lost RevPAR driven by cancellations in Washington and New York due to the severe snowstorm.
As we indicated last year, we also expect to benefit from this construction disruption in 2016 as our maintenance capital spending should decline by more than 18% and the hotels we invested in last year not only face an easier year-over-year comp, but also have an approved product to sell. Given all these factors, we projected in 2016 total comparable hotel RevPAR will increase by 3% to 4% in constant currency and EBITDA margins will increase 0 to 40 basis points. This will translate to adjusted EBITDA of $1.450 billion to $1.480 billion and adjusted FFO per share of $1.65 to $1.69.
It is worth noting that our EBITDA and FFO estimates have been reduced by $14 million to reflect the impact of the $215 million of 2016 asset sales we have identified. However, our balance sheet does not reflect the receipt of the proceeds that these sales will generate.
Overall, I'm pleased to say that we are still seeing positive indicators within our portfolio, with continued strong demand, especially in the group segment. The capital we have invested in our hotels ensures that our portfolio has an excellent condition and our industry's leading balance sheet remains strong. We also remained focused on generating cash from asset sales and operations that can be deployed stock repurchases and returning value to our shareholders. We are confident in the future of our business and our entire team is built focus on delivering another positive year of growth. 
Thank you, and I'll let me turn the call over to Greg Larson, our Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss our operating and financial performance in more detail.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. Despite the fourth quarter headwinds that Ed described, several of our important markets, including Florida, Los Angeles, Atlanta, San Diego and Boston, experienced excellent RevPAR growth and continued to give us confidence as we look ahea
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed. Despite the fourth quarter headwinds that Ed described, several of our important markets, including Florida, Los Angeles, Atlanta, San Diego and Boston, experienced excellent RevPAR growth and continued to give us confidence as we look ahead into 2016.
Let me provide some specific commentary on our major markets. Florida performed very well, and produced the best domestic market performance, with 11.7% RevPAR growth in the fourth quarter, 310 basis points above the STAR upper upscale market RevPAR. Strong group business at our Orlando World Center, Ritz-Carlton Naples, Harbor Beach Marriott and Tampa Airport Marriott, contributed to high average rate growth at these properties.
With the group revenue increase of almost 22%, our managers at our Florida hotels were able to institute more aggressive pricing strategies, which increased transient rates by approximately 7%. In addition, strong group business resulted in more than 23% growth in food and beverage revenues. 
RevPAR at the hotels in Los Angeles grew 9.8% in the fourth quarter, as several of our properties benefited from renovations that occurred during the same time last year. Once again, strong RevPAR growth in Los Angeles was the result of robust average rate growth of more than 5% in both transient and group business.
On the back of group business strength at our hotels, our managers were able to drive food and beverage revenue growth of more than 17%. Looking forward, group booking pays in Los Angeles looks very strong as the market is expected to host 8 additional citywide in 2016. As a result, we expect continued solid performance from our Los Angeles properties.
In Atlanta, RevPAR increased 8.2% for the quarter, primarily as a result of average rate growth of 6.3%. Transient average rate increased 6.6% and 5.2%, respectively. Food and beverage revenues at our properties in the market grew by 8.7%, mainly due to healthy banquet and catering business at the JW Marriott and Grand Hyatt Marriott hotel. We expect our asset in Atlanta will continue to have a solid year in 2016, based on an excellent group booking pays for the year. Atlanta is expected to add more than 8,500 room nights related to 2 additional megacitywide. Our hotels in San Diego produce results that outperformed the average of our portfolio, with RevPAR increasing by 7.5% in the fourth quarter. The Manchester Grand Hyatt benefited from having all of its meeting space available for bookings after renovations last year.
In addition, our managers in San Diego strategically focused on group business at the expense of transient room nights to drive the hotel's overall average rate. In the quarter, group demand increased 7.3% and transient room nights fell 9.8%. As hotels filled with group business, it enabled our managers to become more aggressive with average rate, which resulted in group and transient average rate growth of 9.2% and 7.5%, respectively.
Overall, group revenues increased by more than 17%, contributing to a food and beverage revenue increase of nearly 18%, while transient revenues declined 3%. 
I should point out that nearly all of the increase in food and beverage came from the more profitable banquet and catering business. We expect the trend of our San Diego Hotel outperforming the portfolio to continue in 2016. Even though the city is expected to have fewer citywides this year, total room nights from the citywide is expected to increase by more than 20%. 
In Boston, our assets outperformed the portfolio average with a RevPAR increase of 6.9%, driven by an occupancy gain of 3.5%, coupled with an average rate increase of 1.9%. 
In October, group room nights where our properties in the market grew at 24.4%, with a 3.5% increase in average rates, again, this helps contribute to an 18% increase in food and beverage revenues this quarter. As we look forward to 2016, I would note that although the Boston market is expected to have an average number of citywide, the Convention Center is expected to host 5 additional events. This bodes well for both our Boston Marriott and Sheraton Boston Hotels as we expect these hotels to benefit from these additional events and lead our Boston hotels supposed solid results in 2016.
Moving to some of our markets that witnessed some weakness in the quarter. RevPAR at our hotels in D.C. increased 0.6%, with average rate growth of 1.6%, and an occupancy decline of 70 basis points. The main reason for properties in the markets underperforming the STAR upper upscale market by 250 basis points was due to a combination of the lack of in-house groups and softer transient business.
In 2016, the number of citywide events was flat 2015. However, the number of citywide room nights was up approximately 85,000 over last year. For 2016, the group booking pays for our D.C. hotels was very strong and many of these hotels are expected to benefit from substantial renovations that were completed in 2015.
Unfortunately, RevPAR at our assets in Houston declined 1.1%. However, the good news is that our properties outperformed the STAR upper upscale markets by 690 basis points. The decline in the market continues to be attributable to an overall slowdown in the Houston economy as a result of severely depressed oil prices, increasing market supply and specifically for Host, the renovation of the Houston Marriott Medical Center Hotel.
Our managers continue to focus on growing group room nights to offset the transient decline caused by weaker market fundamentals. We do not expect Houston's market conditions to improve in 2016, therefore, we expect these hotels to continue underperforming the portfolio. Bear in mind that the hotels in the Houston market represent only 2% of our total EBITDA.
Likewise, our New York hotels experienced a 2.4% RevPAR decline in the fourth quarter, slightly outperforming the STAR upper upscale market RevPAR decline of 2.5%. Much of the weakness was due to average rate, which decreased 2%, although occupancy declined 40 basis points. These results continued to indicate that the well-understood supply in the market and a decrease in demand from international travelers, due to the strength of the U.S. dollar, are impacting the overall marketability to raise rates. We expect RevPAR in New York to significantly lag the portfolio in 2016, and acknowledge that the dynamics that impacted the market in 2015 will likely persist this year.
Moving to our international assets. These hotels in an impressive constant of dollar RevPAR growth of 15.5% in the quarter. Latin America drove much of the international growth, with a constant dollar RevPAR increase of 39%. This growth was spurred by the benefit of the renovated hotels at JW Marriott Mexico City, despite economic turmoil related to weakness in the global oil markets and tourism issues related to Zika virus in Brazil, the JW Marriott Rio had an outstanding quarter.
As we continued to simplify the portfolio through non-core asset sales of both Latin America and Asia-Pacific, we expect the EBITDA impact from our international hotels to decline.
Shifting to our European joint venture. Despite the negative impact of the terrorist attacks in Paris in the subsequent lockdown in Brussels, our assets in the region performed relatively well with a constant year of RevPAR increase of 1.7% for the quarter as the significant decline in RevPAR at the hotels in these 2 markets were more than offset by the robust growth of more than 10% at the hotels in our other European markets. RevPAR increase was due to an increase in average rate of over 6%, which was offset by a decline in occupancy of about 3 percentage points. As occupancies for both transient and group business declined, it is encouraging to see that our managers were able to increase transient and group rates in the quarter by 6% and 10%, respectively.
There were some uncertainties surrounding 2016 in light of the 2015 Paris terrorist attack and economic and political recovery that is ongoing in the European Union. However, many positive market fundamentals exist, including the fact that supply remains low in Europe at approximately 1%, and weak euro to the U.S. dollar will likely drive demand from the U.S. to Europe, and the economic environment in Europe is cautiously optimistic.
Now, let's move to our forecast for 2016. With respect to the RevPAR guidance we gave today of 3% to 4% for the portfolio, it is worth noting that we expect 13 of our top 17 domestic markets to experience RevPAR growth that will exceed the high end of our portfolio RevPAR forecast. These markets are expected to perform well based on advanced group bookings, less capital disruption and lower supply. In fact, we expect some of our best-performing markets will be Los Angeles, San Diego, Phoenix, Atlanta and New Orleans. However, the challenges in New York and Houston will continue in 2016.
Other factors to keep in mind for 2016 are the calendar shift as these will affect the overall quarterly results. Eastern moves to the first quarter and a Jewish holiday to the fourth quarter this year. This is reflect it in our group bookings as they are strongest in the second and third quarters, but still positive in all 4 quarters. We expect approximately 22% to 22.5% of our total EBITDA for the year to be generated in the first quarter.
As disclosed in our press release, during the fourth quarter, we repurchased 19.6 million shares to our total purchase price of $325 million, bringing a total for 2015 to 38.3 million shares of common stock, for a total purchase price of approximately 675 million. We currently have $325 million of capacity under the repurchase program.
With respect to dividends, we paid a regular fourth quarter dividend of $0.20 per share, which represents a yield of 5.4% on the current stock price. Further, as stated in today's press release, the Board of Directors authorized a regular first quarter dividend of $0.20 per share on its common stock.
Given our strong operating outlook and significant free cash flow generation, we are committed to sustaining a meaningful dividend. In addition, based on the robust asset sales plan we've outlined and continued to execute on, we anticipate that asset sales will likely result in taxable gains, which could lead to special dividends. While these special dividends will vary and the one-time distribution, they should result in a meaningful return to our stockholders.
Moving to one of our key pillars of strength and competitive advantage, our balance sheet. In 2015, we repaid or refinanced more than $1.4 billion of debt with a weighted average interest rate of 5%, with proceeds from the issuance of $1.5 billion of debt with a weighted average rate of 3.1%. As a result of these transactions, we decreased our weighted average interest rate by 110 basis points to 3.7% and lowered our annualized interest expense by $24 million to $165 million, and extended our weighted average debt maturity by 0.8 years to 6 yes. We have no significant maturities until 2019 and our operating position, financial strength and flexibility.
At year-end, we had approximately $239 million of cash, $702 million in available capacity under our revolving credit facility and $4 billion of debt, while maintaining a leverage within our stated goals of 2.5 to 3x.
In summary, we feel good about the results -- about our results and accomplishments in 2015 and look forward to a solid year of growth in 2016, as we believe the softness we witnessed in transit business in the fourth quarter will be offset by our aggressive asset management strategies and the tailwinds we received from our comprehensive capital program in 2015.
This concludes our prepared remarks. We are now interested in answering any questions you may have.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not really, Smedes, but that's really reflecting the fact that realistically since summer it's been clear that the pool of buyers assets, second half of '15 and into '16, it's a bit smaller than where it was it's say in 2014, primarily because the REITs a
componenttext: Not really, Smedes, but that's really reflecting the fact that realistically since summer it's been clear that the pool of buyers assets, second half of '15 and into '16, it's a bit smaller than where it was it's say in 2014, primarily because the REITs are not aggressive buyers at this point in time. So I think we've launched those particular sales with an understanding that we were appealing primarily to 2 groups, private buyers most often working with operators, and then international buyers who are probably also either using existing operators of the hotels aligned with the new operator. And so with that, I'd say that we had -- I think I'll cost little bit to be, at the last call, interest has been solid, it's probably not as deep as it has been in the past, but it's too it's more than 1 person that's bidding on individual deals. I think we're getting very comfortable with the quality of the bids we're getting. And we continued to feel comfortable that we'll continue to close sales in the pace that we've been on.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the other thing I just wanted to ask you as a follow-up, you talked about group trends, pacing up around 6% for 2016 on revenues, have you seen anything over the last several months, since you last call in terms of the tenor of corporations
componenttext: Okay. And then the other thing I just wanted to ask you as a follow-up, you talked about group trends, pacing up around 6% for 2016 on revenues, have you seen anything over the last several months, since you last call in terms of the tenor of corporations willing to book group or kind of just the pace, relative to the kind of backdrop or the issues we've seen around the economic growth?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: All we have seen on the group side, really throughout '15 and then looking at '16, and at this point, frankly looking further down the road into '17, is good, strong group bookings. And it's carried all the way through last year. And we expect to see that
componenttext: All we have seen on the group side, really throughout '15 and then looking at '16, and at this point, frankly looking further down the road into '17, is good, strong group bookings. And it's carried all the way through last year. And we expect to see that continue this year.

componenttext: Harry, I don't think -- there's always ebbs and flows at individual events. I think Greg might have described a little bit of that. But reality is, so far in terms of what we've been seeing over the last couple of months, we haven't seen any signs of weakness in attendance at events.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my second question is, could you give us an assessment of the condition of your current portfolio, and specifically, you did give us guidance as to how much less you're going to be spending in 2016, as you look even further ahead, and that'
componenttext: Okay. And then my second question is, could you give us an assessment of the condition of your current portfolio, and specifically, you did give us guidance as to how much less you're going to be spending in 2016, as you look even further ahead, and that's  there's no budgeting done it, but do you think that your CapEx in the 2017 can keep declining?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our expectation at this point would be the 2017 would be at -- should be above where we are in '16. Our goal for the last 2 years has been '16 and '17 would be low our CapEx years. I think it's still hard to anticipate beyond that, but we're expecting lev
componenttext: Our expectation at this point would be the 2017 would be at -- should be above where we are in '16. Our goal for the last 2 years has been '16 and '17 would be low our CapEx years. I think it's still hard to anticipate beyond that, but we're expecting level similar to where we are on the maintenance CapEx side. And then as it relates to what we would describe as ROI, or redevelopment CapEx, that will depend upon what projects we might identify for '17. At this stage, I don't know that there's anything specifically on the books. So if I had to predict today what would happen in '17, I would expect to see that spending decline.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess what I was specifically asking also is just your qualitative assessment of your portfolio and are there any glaring CapEx requirements that you need to address?
componenttext: I guess what I was specifically asking also is just your qualitative assessment of your portfolio and are there any glaring CapEx requirements that you need to address?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would think that the quality of our portfolio is quite good at this point in time. We have spent heavily on the portfolio over the course of the last several years. So when we measure the portfolio in terms of its effect of age, that number is as attrac
componenttext: I would think that the quality of our portfolio is quite good at this point in time. We have spent heavily on the portfolio over the course of the last several years. So when we measure the portfolio in terms of its effect of age, that number is as attractive as it has ever been looking at how recently the rooms have been done, how recently is the meeting space has been done, how many lobbies our food and beverage outlets have been done. So I don't see that if I -- there's always going to be an asset or 2 where we made a conscious decision not to do capital for a variety of reasons, and some of those are the ones that we're intending on selling, because we think that allowing the buyer to do that capital will ultimately enhance the total price that they be able to pay for the assets taking into account the CapEx that might be required. But outside of some handful of unique situations like that, our portfolio is in good shape. And the fact that we're spending less this year, and most likely next year, is not an indication of shorting the portfolio of capital that it needs, it's more an indication that we're in good condition.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Robert Farley with UBS.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Robert Farley with UBS.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could quantify in your RevPAR guidance of -- the up 3% to 4%, how much of that is helped by the renovation. You mentioned, those 4 properties that had significant renovations and I think you had initially expected Q4 RevPAR in '15 to be yo
componenttext: I wonder if you could quantify in your RevPAR guidance of -- the up 3% to 4%, how much of that is helped by the renovation. You mentioned, those 4 properties that had significant renovations and I think you had initially expected Q4 RevPAR in '15 to be your best RevPAR quarter for the year, because of those renovations, so I assumed some of the 3% to 4%, I don't know if you have that fully adjusted, not including the benefit of that renovation?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me provide some clarity on that. Because in a couple of the writeups that I saw this morning, I could tell that folks that weren't exactly following the differences between some of these assets. So most specifically, the 4 assets that I reference
componenttext: Yes. Let me provide some clarity on that. Because in a couple of the writeups that I saw this morning, I could tell that folks that weren't exactly following the differences between some of these assets. So most specifically, the 4 assets that I referenced when I was talking about the ones that are going to have a significant improvement on a year-over-year basis, so The Logan and Philly, The Camby in Phoenix, the Houston Airport Marriott, and the Axiom in San Francisco. All of those hotels are for our RevPAR purposes, are forecast non-comparable. So the incredible increase in revenues that we will see at those hotels is not included in our RevPAR forecast. And so that's one of the reasons why I think people as -- we are getting the lift from that and we're trying to describe the lift that we're getting from an EBITDA perspective, but the benefits of that are not showing up in our comparable RevPAR numbers, those numbers will not likely show up until most likely '17, when those projects have been in our portfolio operating on a stable -- not stabilized fashion, but operating as a complete the total for a full year. So we'll see the lift in '17 from those assets, but we're not going to see any lift in our '16 reported RevPAR from those assets.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess you had other renovations as well during the year last year, and your guidance for Q4, you had originally said, that the RevPAR would benefit in Q4, would be the best of the 4 quarters, because of renovations? So even if it's not those 4 specific
componenttext: I guess you had other renovations as well during the year last year, and your guidance for Q4, you had originally said, that the RevPAR would benefit in Q4, would be the best of the 4 quarters, because of renovations? So even if it's not those 4 specific sort of major, where you closed the property for a time, can you talk about the benefit of renovations at other properties that might be included there?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Robin, I think we did see some -- we did expect to see some benefit in the fourth quarter from less construction disruptions. So you're right about that. And I would say that Indian, I don't know the RevPAR -- our RevPAR came in below where we had anticip
componenttext: Robin, I think we did see some -- we did expect to see some benefit in the fourth quarter from less construction disruptions. So you're right about that. And I would say that Indian, I don't know the RevPAR -- our RevPAR came in below where we had anticipated it and I think that was not unique to us, that was really an industrywide phenomenon. We did see pickup at the number of the properties that we're under renovations. I don't know that we would necessarily view it as overly significant in the fourth quarter. A lot of those renovations had started at the very end of the quarter. And frankly, with December being a low occupancy month, I don't know that we necessarily saw as much benefit in '15 as we might have anticipated. We will see some lift and some positive benefits from that in the first half of the year. And I suspect that one of the reasons why our portfolio performed so much better than the industry in January, despite the fact that we had even with the winter storm that hit the northeast, it's in part due to the fact that we had -- we did not have as much renovation activity at some of those hotels.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Thank you for clarifying. And then just lastly real quick. You mentioned your maintenance CapEx -- renewal replacement CapEx is going to be down $60 million in '16, it looks like in Q4, it came in like close to $35 million or $40 million high
componenttext: Okay, great. Thank you for clarifying. And then just lastly real quick. You mentioned your maintenance CapEx -- renewal replacement CapEx is going to be down $60 million in '16, it looks like in Q4, it came in like close to $35 million or $40 million higher than what you had guided to your renewal replacement Q4, is some of that is that may be a timing issue that some of that renewal replacement CapEx came in into Q4 that was originally planned for '16?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say that it was probably -- the short answer is, yes, I think some of that probably has more to do with the timing of when payments were made as opposed to necessarily when the work was completed. But the short answer is yes.
componenttext: Yes, I would say that it was probably -- the short answer is, yes, I think some of that probably has more to do with the timing of when payments were made as opposed to necessarily when the work was completed. But the short answer is yes.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Shaun Kelley with Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Shaun Kelley with Bank of America.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned a little bit more detail on supply growth and how that sort of overlays with the demand environment that you're seeing out there, particularly in some of the urban areas, I was curious if you could just dig in o
componenttext: Ed, in your prepared remarks, you mentioned a little bit more detail on supply growth and how that sort of overlays with the demand environment that you're seeing out there, particularly in some of the urban areas, I was curious if you could just dig in on that a little bit more for us, I mean there's -- how generally do you guys seek to react or do you try and manage the portfolio in an environment where demand may -- where are the one side, depends at peak levels, but on the other second of demand may actually not keep up with supply growth that you're seeing, at least in a handful of markets?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I know I'd say sort of 2 ways to look at this, one element of it is that as we look down the road and there -- as we anticipate markets might see increased supply, that does play into some of the decisions we made relative to whether that we retained
componenttext: Yes. I know I'd say sort of 2 ways to look at this, one element of it is that as we look down the road and there -- as we anticipate markets might see increased supply, that does play into some of the decisions we made relative to whether that we retained asset or whether we try to market it. So there is sort of a long strategic perspective that addresses that. As we look at it from a more near-term operating perspective, if we see markets that are likely to get additional supply and we think that, that could may have an impact on our property, and that may guide some of our strategies in those markets relative to the level of groups that we would want and the level of say Special Corporate business that we might try to attract for that individual hotel. So in the markets where we've seen, such as in New York, there's no secret that New York got a lot of supply, and we have consciously tried to improve the level of group activity that we do in that market as a way to offset some of the increased supply that we expect to see.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Anthony Powell with Barclays.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Anthony Powell with Barclays.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: One more question on group, how in the quarter for fourth quarter group bookings track in 4Q? And how do you expect that part of the business to trend going forward?
componenttext: One more question on group, how in the quarter for fourth quarter group bookings track in 4Q? And how do you expect that part of the business to trend going forward?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know that I don't know that I have that number right here in front of me. I would say that in the quarter, for the quarter was probably, I'd rather not guess. I know that the bookings in the quarter for '16 were solid and we're running north of 4.5%,
componenttext: You know that I don't know that I have that number right here in front of me. I would say that in the quarter, for the quarter was probably, I'd rather not guess. I know that the bookings in the quarter for '16 were solid and we're running north of 4.5%, so the activity that we had booking for the future was quite good. The way the third -- the fourth quarter played out, my guess is at the end of the quarter fourth quarter bookings were not particularly strong, but the reason for that was the bulk of the group's strength was really in the first 5 to 6 weeks of the quarter. It was -- October was filled because you had have the movement in the holiday, the Jewish holiday, from September from October to prior year into September. So October was a very busy month, but there wasn't really any capacity at the hotels to take a lot of additional group. And once we got beyond that period of time, you really at the stage during the year when there's not a lot of group pickup in general. So I think the activity in the fourth quarter was not particularly remarkable in the quarter for the quarter, but it continued to be strong for the future.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. '16, as Ed mentioned, but also for '17 as well.
componenttext: Yes. '16, as Ed mentioned, but also for '17 as well.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And I think you mentioned OTA rate was down for the fourth quarter, how are you approaching your OTA kind of allocations in '16? And what are the operators doing I guess to reduce the industry reliance on OTAs going forward?
componenttext: Got it. And I think you mentioned OTA rate was down for the fourth quarter, how are you approaching your OTA kind of allocations in '16? And what are the operators doing I guess to reduce the industry reliance on OTAs going forward?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say, in general, because the hotels are running at high occupancies, and because the operators especially the major operators are refining their strategies in terms of their relationships with the OTAs, we're generally seeing that business, t
componenttext: Yes. I would say, in general, because the hotels are running at high occupancies, and because the operators especially the major operators are refining their strategies in terms of their relationships with the OTAs, we're generally seeing that business, the rate of growth there is slower than in some of the other segments. I think what we ran into in the fourth quarter was because we did see what is generally assumed to be some weakness in corporate travel, there was a little bit more use of OTA options than we had necessarily predicted and what do so with that was slightly lower pricing in an effort to attract more of that business. So the good news is that we were able to get occupancy by opening up those channels to a greater degree. But unfortunately, when you watch how across the country some of that was a lower rate than what we have done in the prior year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And a small follow-up to that question, corporate negotiated rates, you mentioned that they are higher, how do you kind of avoid a replay of that in the coming quarters?
componenttext: And a small follow-up to that question, corporate negotiated rates, you mentioned that they are higher, how do you kind of avoid a replay of that in the coming quarters?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it's hard -- it's obviously hard to stimulate demand in corporate travel, and history has shown us in prior times that you don't stimulate that demand by dropping price. So I think the way our approach was, was to generally across the portfolio, foc
componenttext:
Well, it's hard -- it's obviously hard to stimulate demand in corporate travel, and history has shown us in prior times that you don't stimulate that demand by dropping price. So I think the way our approach was, was to generally across the portfolio, focused is on the difference on assets and take into account the market factors and individual markets and then 
look to try to generate, take advantage of the high occupancies to generate better rate growth than those corporate negotiations, but also firm up in markets where you thought you wanted it at some additional accounts.
To put some math around that, what we're looking at on kind of a comparable basis in the beginning of the year as our special corporate rates at least looking at things that are buy in the first quarter, up north of 5%. And last year, we were more in the 3% range. So there's a nice opportunity there to see some better results because of improved special corporate rates.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move next to Ryan Meliker with Canaccord Genuity.
componenttext: And we'll move next to Ryan Meliker with Canaccord Genuity.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: most of my questions have been answered, but, first of all, thanks for a lot of the color on the guidance and how the renovations are playing out. Just one quick question, I had regarding group pays, obviously I think in 3Q your group pays was up 6.5% it'
componenttext: most of my questions have been answered, but, first of all, thanks for a lot of the color on the guidance and how the renovations are playing out. Just one quick question, I had regarding group pays, obviously I think in 3Q your group pays was up 6.5% it's held steady around that level for 2016, but what we saw in January from the SPR data, was group was off dramatically, only up about 1.5%. Is that indicative across your portfolio too? And is that timing that you talked about with some of the calendar shift that I know they haven't materialized yet, but you're seeing those sluggish group out of the gate for the first quarter for your portfolio and for the broader industry?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So not entirely, we actually saw -- we don't -- I don't have the segment results yet for January, but based on the bookings that we were anticipating and I don't have any indications of things that it turned out radically different from that. We were expe
componenttext: So not entirely, we actually saw -- we don't -- I don't have the segment results yet for January, but based on the bookings that we were anticipating and I don't have any indications of things that it turned out radically different from that. We were expecting better than what you described in terms of group pace in January and frankly in February. The month that is weaker for us in group on a year-over-year basis is March, and that's I think solely because of the change in the Easter holiday timing. So as we -- I think we commented in our prepared remarks, the first quarter and the fourth quarter are slightly weaker -- if you look -- if you spread our group activity across the year, Q1 and Q2 are still both up, but they're not up as much as Q2 -- Q2 and Q3, which are up significantly in terms of group revenue pace.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. You we're saying Q1 and Q4 are too weak Q2 and Q3.
componenttext: Yes. You we're saying Q1 and Q4 are too weak Q2 and Q3.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Right.
componenttext: Right. Right.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the question that I would have is do you think some of your group's outperformance in the first quarter is more driven by some of the renovations and the types of assets that you have and revenue management strategies? Or do you think it's not so
componenttext: I guess the question that I would have is do you think some of your group's outperformance in the first quarter is more driven by some of the renovations and the types of assets that you have and revenue management strategies? Or do you think it's not so anomalous in favor of your portfolio? I'm just trying to gauge of where group businesses throughout the remainder of the year, not just for you guys, but for the broader industry, in case we're seeing any type of pullback?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think across the industry, I'm continually hearing from everyone that group is fairly solid, but I am sure that we are benefiting a bit from the fact that we have less renovation activity and we have hotels that were under construction last year and now
componenttext: I think across the industry, I'm continually hearing from everyone that group is fairly solid, but I am sure that we are benefiting a bit from the fact that we have less renovation activity and we have hotels that were under construction last year and now are provided either new rooms or new meeting space and is attractive to our customers. So I'm sure, again, going back to our January performance, I'd say some of that is reflective of the fact that we had space available and not under construction.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Steven Kent with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Steven Kent with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question. It sounds like group bookings, as you just mentioned, are in good shape, occupancy expectations and banquet why is the margin outlook only up a modest 0 to 40 basis points? Are we missing something on the expense side because it sou
componenttext: Just a quick question. It sounds like group bookings, as you just mentioned, are in good shape, occupancy expectations and banquet why is the margin outlook only up a modest 0 to 40 basis points? Are we missing something on the expense side because it sounds like you should get some better flow-through? And then just isn't aside, because I think it's an interesting issue that we're starting to hear from some other companies, are you seeing any last-minute or late bookers canceling and rebooking other places? Are you starting to see some of that activity or more churn that you seen before?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, going to your second question first, we have generally seen that problem in a variety of markets, but -- we had not -- we've not identified that in discussions with our operators as the situation that accelerated in the fourth quarter. We have also
componenttext: Steve, going to your second question first, we have generally seen that problem in a variety of markets, but -- we had not -- we've not identified that in discussions with our operators as the situation that accelerated in the fourth quarter. We have also been actively encouraging our operators. And of course, this is one place we're working with a lot of the major operators is probably helpful for us, to push towards pricing strategies that, in effect, create some frictional cost around changing reservations at the last minute. And we will continue to encourage that they look at either nonrefundable rooms or extending the time period for which when you have to cancel in order to make it more difficult for people to reserve a room with us for a long period of time, and then change their mind at the last minute, and rebook elsewhere. For your fundamental point, we do not see an acceleration of that activity in the fourth quarter. On the margin piece of it, you know, I'd say that the some of the fact of the margins, no real expense that we necessarily have highlighted that would drive weaker margin performance. And we still expect values to continue to increase for the hotels and there's always a little bit of a lag on this. The real estate taxes will be jumping by more than inflation on a year-over-year basis. But beyond that.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the one other point I would look at is if you look at our results for 2015, we had 3.8% RevPAR growth and 20 basis points improvement in margin. If you adjust those 2 things -- items for USALI, we really had 4% RevPAR growth, with margins up 35 ba
componenttext: I guess the one other point I would look at is if you look at our results for 2015, we had 3.8% RevPAR growth and 20 basis points improvement in margin. If you adjust those 2 things -- items for USALI, we really had 4% RevPAR growth, with margins up 35 basis points, and so that's pretty similar to our guidance, right? If you look at the high-end of our guidance, we're predicting 4% RevPAR and margins up 40 basis points.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to head back on the guidance for a second here. So I'm curious for what the 3 to 4 range implies for the transient side of the business, if group pays is up around 6, I know that is -- that include some of the renovation tailwinds so it's no
componenttext: I just wanted to head back on the guidance for a second here. So I'm curious for what the 3 to 4 range implies for the transient side of the business, if group pays is up around 6, I know that is -- that include some of the renovation tailwinds so it's not a true same store number, just sort of what the bridges between that and the transient implied figure would be very helpful?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know I guess what I would say was that it wouldn't surprise us if we are up north of 6% right now in terms of group. As we -- because we sold so many rooms already to potential group customers, it wouldn't surprise us that as we work our way through t
componenttext: You know I guess what I would say was that it wouldn't surprise us if we are up north of 6% right now in terms of group. As we -- because we sold so many rooms already to potential group customers, it wouldn't surprise us that as we work our way through the year that the actual increase in group revenues that we experienced by the end of the year would be a smaller number than that. In other words, it's not abnormal to see some follow-up in that area, especially with an extended booking cycle. So my guess is as that we report group revenues throughout the course of the year, the actual beat there will be a little bit less than that. So that probably addresses some of what you're looking at. I'd say more broadly, as we maybe as a more broad commentary on our guidance, in general, our properties are more optimistic than our guidance would necessarily reflect. And we do see some benefits whether it's in the Special Corporate weights that I talked about before, the fact that our government rates are up meaningfully year-over-year, well, that's not a huge job of our business where you see some rate increases. There are a number of factors like that, that will help with transient pricing. We're not expecting a lot of transient occupancy increase, we think it will be primarily a rate gain this year. If we add -- but I think you're right, you're sort of fundamental assumption is that if we hit our numbers, and that hit the projections that we've identified, we're probably see it will be slightly more weighted towards group and slightly less weighted towards transient in terms of revenue growth.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so the group number should still outpace the transient number, in any case?
componenttext: Okay, so the group number should still outpace the transient number, in any case?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That will be our expectation for now, yes.
componenttext: That will be our expectation for now, yes.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I guess as a follow-up to that, so the range of 3 to 4 at this stage in the year, it's pretty tight, only 100 basis points, due to some in up group business on books, you think at this point to peg such a tight range at this point in the calendar?
componenttext: I mean, I guess as a follow-up to that, so the range of 3 to 4 at this stage in the year, it's pretty tight, only 100 basis points, due to some in up group business on books, you think at this point to peg such a tight range at this point in the calendar?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know there are as many people in the room that many different theories on how to approach guidance. I guess what I'd say is that the way we look at it, we're trying to give you our best insight into how we think the year is going to play out, based on
componenttext: You know there are as many people in the room that many different theories on how to approach guidance. I guess what I'd say is that the way we look at it, we're trying to give you our best insight into how we think the year is going to play out, based on the information that we have available to us. And at this -- in the context of this year, we thought that we'd probably us to be a fair on the conservative side, so that is why you see the range that we have.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now move next to Jim Sullivan with Cowen Group.
componenttext: We'll now move next to Jim Sullivan with Cowen Group.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, just to kind of follow on that last question, as well as some of the comments you made in the prepared commentary part of the call, your comments of supply and demand suggest that the negative impact of supply growth will increase over the course of
componenttext: And, just to kind of follow on that last question, as well as some of the comments you made in the prepared commentary part of the call, your comments of supply and demand suggest that the negative impact of supply growth will increase over the course of the year, now we've heard what you've said about the group outlook in Q2 into Q3, but does that mean overall, given that the supply growth will increase over the course of the year, that you expect RevPAR growth overall to be weaker in the second half than the first half?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily, Jim, because as we look at group, the strongest quarter for group bookings is actually in Q3. And so I don't necessarily expect that that's what's going to happen. I don't -- I think that -- I don't know that a lot of these markets supply
componenttext: Not necessarily, Jim, because as we look at group, the strongest quarter for group bookings is actually in Q3. And so I don't necessarily expect that that's what's going to happen. I don't -- I think that -- I don't know that a lot of these markets supply necessarily accelerates through the second half of the year, but that's one of the things we'll need to see how that actually plays out. What we've been noticing in a number of markets over here is that the outlook for supply is in each of the last few years what's expected to be delivered at the beginning of the year and what's actually delivered by the end of the year turns out to be a lower number, because the deliveries don't happen at the same pace it's originally forecasted, so that might help mitigate that. But I'd say, at this stage, as we look at the year, the only reason why I might anticipate that the first half could be a little stronger than the second half as it relates to construction disruption because we had more in the first half than we had in the second half. But based on the discussions we've been having so far, it feels like it's a fairly balanced year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on your prepared comments on the markets, and I might have missed this, but I don't recall your commenting on the outlook for San Francisco and Denver?
componenttext: Okay. And then on your prepared comments on the markets, and I might have missed this, but I don't recall your commenting on the outlook for San Francisco and Denver?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think San Francisco, we're generally expecting to be roughly in line with the rest of the portfolio. So maybe not the top performer that it has been for the last few years. But sort of not -- certainly not in the level where it's going to be a significa
componenttext: I think San Francisco, we're generally expecting to be roughly in line with the rest of the portfolio. So maybe not the top performer that it has been for the last few years. But sort of not -- certainly not in the level where it's going to be a significant underperformer either. There's no doubt that there's some challenges in that market due to the fact that the Convention Center has been closed. The booking pays at our hotels is still up compared to last year. It's not up as much as the overall portfolio, but we were fortunate that the big hotel there, the San Francisco Marquis, is essentially just doing a lot of in-house group business to deal with the fact that the Convention Center will have more closings.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Jim, as I said, 13 of our 17 markets, based on the group booking pays and the supply and some of the other metrics that we mentioned, I said in my prepared remarks, would actually exceed the high end of our guidance, and so San Francisco, certainly wo
componenttext: And Jim, as I said, 13 of our 17 markets, based on the group booking pays and the supply and some of the other metrics that we mentioned, I said in my prepared remarks, would actually exceed the high end of our guidance, and so San Francisco, certainly would be one of those hotels that I included in those 13 markets. Denver, as you know, in the fourth quarter for us, it actually experienced a decline in RevPAR. We think it will turn positive in '16, but I would think Denver will be sort of closer to call it at the midpoint to the high end of our guidance.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Denver is one of those markets where we do have some construction going on. So it's not a big market for us, at leases 1 hotel is the redevelopment hotel and the other has some meeting space being worked on.
componenttext: And Denver is one of those markets where we do have some construction going on. So it's not a big market for us, at leases 1 hotel is the redevelopment hotel and the other has some meeting space being worked on.

componenttext: I would say in the long run, and our goal is to disturb our taxable income and so when we some operations, of course, also from sales. And as we work our way through this year and see both our operating results materialize as well as what's the level of sales that we complete, we will continue to assess whether we should be doing increasing the regular dividend or handling things through a special dividend. Some of that decision will be tied into our outlook for '17 too as we try to confront that question. We, ultimately, are certainly interested in being able to increase the dividend when operations where the operating results of the company's support it  because we love to return capital to shareholders in any way that we can.

componenttext: Ed, you've talked a lot about group and how strong it looks, can you just give a little background on what you think is driving that? Is it tight employment for white-collared workers? And do you have any concerns about weakness in certain industries like energy or emerging weakness in financials or technology?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Be happy to do that, David, let me just look at 1 stats here. You know, the wild card in group over the years has tended to be what I think you were directing your question at, which is happening on the corporate side. And what we saw this past year was f
componenttext: Be happy to do that, David, let me just look at 1 stats here. You know, the wild card in group over the years has tended to be what I think you were directing your question at, which is happening on the corporate side. And what we saw this past year was fairly good, we saw some improvement on the -- in terms of Association. But as I say mentioned in my prepared comments, we saw some really good corporate rate improvement, as well as some improvement in corporate demand in the fourth quarter. And I think what we're looking at in terms of why we've seen an improvement in group pays this year is a combination of a slight, probably a slightly better convention calendar riches affect itself in a slight increase in Association business across all of our hotels. But more importantly, more activity coming out of the corporate side and companies recognizing that they are going to have events and their now of a mind that they're convinced enough that they're going to have them and that they're making a decision to book those events in advance and not wait till the last minute because what they realized if they wait to the last minute, they're not going to end up with the time or the hotels that they want. So I suspect as we work our way through this year, while it's fair to assume that they'll be some pickup in Association business, I'm hopeful that we're going to see good strong corporate growth. That also tends to tie in with the fact that we're -- it could reflect itself in terms of better F&B growth too. So I think, ultimately, because corporate -- the corporate group is the part that ebbs and flows from those, based upon the overall economy, the fact that we are seeing the strong growth is likely  primarily due to strong corporate growth. I'm sure that the oil industry, to your point about different business, I'm sure the oil industry with all the challenges that they have, is not necessarily booking as many group events as they might have in the past. So it is sort of interesting to see, as Greg just referenced, how strong our group booking pays is in Houston. I suspect that has more to do with a smaller, overall group profile for the hotel. But I don't know that we've heard of any other industry besides the energy industry that's cutting back at this point. If anything, our numbers, which again as we suggested, not only strong for '16, they're strong for '17, that suggested there's meaningful level of confidence in companies that are making commitments.

But that is another asset in New York that we would certainly be open to selling. The opportunity in New York, in order to get the sort of pricing that tends to make the headline, is to take advantage of assets where there's either an opportunity for a brand change or there's an opportunity for redevelopment. That's where that you can best take advantage of the property that you own, and so those are the sorts of opportunities that we're trying to explore. We -- certainly in that $800 million of assets that we're currently marketing that does include the New York asset and completing a sale in New York continues to be a very high priority for the company, provided we can attract pricing that we think is appropriate.
