Good day, and welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts Incorporated First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, out of could on the conference over to Ms. Gee Lingberg, Vice President. PDM.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Eric. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Before we begin, I would like to remind everyone that many of the comments made today are considered to be forward-looking statements under fede
componenttext:
Thanks, Eric. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. 
Before we begin, I would like to remind everyone that many of the comments made today are considered to be forward-looking statements under federal securities laws. As described in our filings with the SEC, these statements are subject to numerous risks and uncertainties that could cause future results to differ from those expressed and we're not obligated to publicly update or revise these forward-looking statements.
In addition, on today's call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial information, such as FFO, adjusted EBITDA and comparable hotel results. You can find this information, together with reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP information, in today's earnings press release, and our 8-K filed with the SEC and the supplemental financial information on our website, at hosthotels.com. 
With me on the call today is Ed Walter, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Larson, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, Ed will provide a brief overview of our first quarter results and then we'll discuss our disposition activity as well as the company's outlook for 2016. Greg will then provide greater detail on our first quarter performance byes market. Following their remarks, we will be available to respond to your questions. 
And now, I would like to turn the call over to Ed.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gee. Good morning, everyone. We're pleased to report that 2016 is off to a solid start on multiple fronts. Less disruption from renovation allow our hotels to outperform the industry on the top line in the quarter and contributed to better-than-ex
componenttext:
Thanks, Gee. Good morning, everyone. We're pleased to report that 2016 is off to a solid start on multiple fronts. Less disruption from renovation allow our hotels to outperform the industry on the top line in the quarter and contributed to better-than-expected improvements in margins and profitability. We also continue to make progress on the initiatives we commenced in 2015 to position Host Hotels for continued growth and value creation, including the disposition of non-core assets and returning capital to shareholders. 
Let's start with a review of our results. Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter was $345 million, which is reflects an increase of 7.5% over last year and which exceeded both our expectations and consensus estimates. Our first quarter adjusted FFO per diluted share was $0.41, exceeding consensus estimates and reflecting 17% increase over last year. These results were driven by several factors. First, the demand growth in our portfolio was quite strong, as comparable hotel occupancy grew by 2.1 percentage points, allowing the portfolio to achieve 75.5% occupancy, which represents our highest Q1 occupancy rate since 2000. While we attribute roughly half of this occupancy growth to the reduced levels of construction disruption, overall still reflects solid demand growth for our hotels.
When combined with average rate growth of 0.7%, the comparable hotel portfolio achieved RevPAR growth of 3.6% in constant currency, which exceeded the industry luxury upper upscale average by 170 basis points. The strong demand growth we experienced was driven primarily by our transient segment. Our transient demand reduced for the effect of extra day related to leap year was up 5%, solid improvements across all segments other than Special Corporate. Transient demand growth was the highest in February and March, with the latter aided by the Easter holiday which accelerated Spring travel. Adversely, our group business experience the demand decrease of slightly more than 2% for the quarter, which was generally caused by a very weak March, driven by the shift in the Easter holiday. And what we do is a favorable sign, corporate group actually increased 2.7% during the quarter. However, that increase was offset by slide decline in association business, and a larger decline in other group, which was related in part to the changing value of the NBA All Star games in New York in 2015 to Toronto in 2016. Strong increases in corporate group rate helped drive an overall group ADR increase of 1.8%, which translated into a slight increase in total group revenue. We expected lower level of group activity contributed to a moderate comparable hotel SMB revenue growth of just 1%. As banquet growth slightly less than 1% and outlooks grew by 1.4%. We expect these growth levels to improve going forward, as group activity picks up again in subsequent quarters. With other revenue growth improving by 3.7%, overall revenues grew by 3.2%. As Greg will describe in more detail, lower utility cost and the implementation of new operating methods allowed us to increase comparable hotel EBITDA margin by 90 basis points, which exceeded our expectations and contributed to solid hotel EBITDA growth of 6.8%.
As we've discussed on prior calls, we are very focused on actively managing our portfolio and efficiently allocating capital. We continue to make good progress on our asset sale program with the asset sales completed during the first quarter, generating proceeds of over $120 million. We have 5 additional assets under contract, representing gross proceeds of $340 million. The closing is anticipated during second quarter. Given our general goal of operating the portfolio, as we complete these sales, it is worth noting that the average RevPAR of these sold or under contract hotels is $112, which falls far short of our first quarter portfolio average of $166. In addition to these expected dispositions, we are currently marketing roughly another $0.5 billion worth of assets. While the market is not as robust as last year, we are seeing some signs of improvement in the debt market and believe that we will be successful in selling additional hotels through the remainder of the year, assuming current market conditions continue.
As we previously discussed, these asset sales will generate tax gains, which will likely require special dividend at year end. Given that our current stock price is trading in a meaningful discount NAV, we believe that the primary use of sale proceeds an excess of dividends and debt repayment requirements is to buyback our stock. We repurchased an additional $81 million in stock this quarter, bringing our total in $758 million since the institution of our initial program in April of last year. In combination with our recent dividend payments, we have returned more than $230 million to shareholders in the last 60 days. 
Now let me spend a few minutes on our outlook for the remainder of 2016. As I mentioned, our results in Q1 exceeded our expectation and we continue to anticipate even stronger results in Q2 and Q3. Given that our group revenue pace in these 2 quarters were up more than 6.5% and generally higher occupancy we typically run during those months, usually in excess of 80%, should help drive better improvement in ADR. At this point, we anticipate that we will experience a more muted, but still positive fourth quarter, as the Jewish holiday shift and nationwide election will reduce demand and the traditionally lower occupancies in the fourth quarter could restrain rate growth.
Looking at comparable hotel RevPAR on a full year perspective, we remain very comfortable with our full year range of 3% to 4%. Given our strong first quarter comparable hotel EBITDA margin growth, we're increasing our range of full year improvement to 25 basis points to 65 basis points. This should translate to a fully adjusted EBITDA of $1,440,000,000 to $1,475,000,000 and FFO per share of $1.65 to $1.69. It is important to note that our EBITDA estimate for the year was previously reduced by $14 million for the sales that we had closed or under contract in February and has been reduced by an incremental $16 million today for the additional sales we have identified. Have we not place this letter assets on under contract, our EBITDA range would've increased by approximately $9 million at the midpoint from our prior guidance. That being said, we're confident that we are taking a disciplined approach to portfolio management and continuing to dispose off non-core assets to better position us for -- in the long run versus future growth and success.
In summary, we are very pleased with our strong first quarter results and remain confident about our outlook for the remainder of 2016. With that, we'll turn the call over to Greg Larson, our Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss our operating and financial performance in much greater detail.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. Overall, we're pleased with our solid results this quarter. The domestic markets that outperformed the portfolio were San Francisco, Los Angeles, D.C. and Atlanta. While Latin America was the outperformer in our international markets. Sever
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed. Overall, we're pleased with our solid results this quarter. The domestic markets that outperformed the portfolio were San Francisco, Los Angeles, D.C. and Atlanta. While Latin America was the outperformer in our international markets. Several of our hotels in markets such as Denver, Boston, San Diego, Phoenix and Chicago had a slower start, but are expected to improve throughout the rest of the year. First, I'll provide some specific commentary on our major markets. Our hotels in San Francisco had an impressive quarter, with RevPAR growing 12.5% on a difficult comp of 15.4% growth last year.
San Francisco hosted the Superbowl this quarter and all of the RevPAR growth came from double-digit ADR gains or a total increase in ADR of 12.7%. In addition, occupancy remained stable at a very high 80%. However, we expect the expansion of the Moscone Convention Center will negatively impact the San Francisco hotels for the remainder of 2016. As a result, our San Francisco hotel may underperform portfolio in the remaining quarters. RevPAR at our properties in Los Angeles grew 12.8% in the first quarter, driven by an 8.7% increase in ADR and a 2.6 percentage point increase in occupancy 82.3%. A solid group a at our Marina Del Ray, Ritz-Carlton and Marriott Hotel, long transient demand at several of our other hotels and tailwinds from the new Beach debut Western South Coast Plaza renovations last year drove a RevPAR increase this quarter. 
Looking forward, group bookings in Los Angeles looks very strong, as the market is expected to host additional citywides this year. As a result, we expect good performance from our Los Angeles properties. Despite the negative impact of the major East Coast Nordstrom in Germany, RevPAR at our D.C. Hotels increased 7.3%, significantly outperforming the STAR upper upscale RevPAR increase of only 0.4%. This increase was primarily driven by 4.3 percentage point increase in occupancy as well as average rate growth of 0.7%.
Several of our D.C. hotels benefited from renovations completed last year. Based on strong bookings faced for these hotels, combined with our expectations that we will continue to see benefits from our completed renovation, we expect our properties in D.C. to achieve solid results in the second quarter. In Atlanta, RevPAR increased 5.2% for the quarter, as a result of average rate growth of 3.5% and occupancy increase of 1.2 percentage points. Our hotel operators successfully executed on their strategy to grow weekend and room night. The supply in the market well below the historical average. Strong group revenues in first and the second quarter, we expect our assets in Atlanta to continue to outperform the portfolio in the second quarter.
Shifting to markets that underperformed the portfolio this quarter. Denver was the worst performing market in the portfolio, with a RevPAR decline of 2.8%. We primarily attribute this to the renovations of the West and Denver Hotel and a supply increase in the downtown corridor, which is impacting the hotel to pull these drive rate and occupancies. Despite these factors, our Denver hotels outpaced the STAR upper upscale results by 90 basis points. We expect results to improve at our hotels in Denver in the second quarter. Our Boston hotels experienced a RevPAR decline of 1.9% in the first quarter, driven entirely by a rate decrease of 3%, while occupancy improved 80 basis points.
A decrease in citywide this quarter caused our hotel operators to shift from higher rated group business to lower rated transient business. The entire Boston market was challenged, as evidenced by the STAR upper upscale RevPAR decline of 30 basis points. We anticipate that with the additional citywide events, scheduled at the Heinz Convention Center for the remainder of year, resulted Boston hotels will strengthen going forward. 
RevPAR at our assets in San Diego declined 80 basis points this quarter, due to the renovation of the Coronado Marriott and a higher mix of lower rated group business to offset a shortage of citywide room night. Despite the slow start in San Diego, we expect the hotels in this market will strengthen through the rest of 2016, as the city is expected to benefit from an increase in citywide room nights for the remainder of the year, especially in the third quarter. 
Moving to Phoenix. Hotel RevPAR increased 10 basis points in the quarter due to the difficult comparison of a Super Bowl benefit last year. Despite that, we outperformed the STAR upper upscale RevPAR by 70 basis points.
Phoenix is another market with supply is still projected to be below the historical average. That, combined with a strong bookings phase in the second and fourth quarters, just translate to our properties outperforming our portfolio for the rest of the year. Our hotels in Florida underperformed the portfolio, with RevPAR increase of only 40 basis points. Milder weather in the midwest and northeast, but cold-weather in January and February in Florida, the media coverage of the Zica, decrease in international travel and continued new supply hampered growth in the first quarter. Based on the weakness experienced in the first quarter, we anticipate our hotels in Florida to underperform the portfolio in the second quarter. 
While RevPAR at our Chicago assets improved to 30 basis points, our properties outperformed the STAR upper scale marked by 860 basis points due to the benefits from room renovations at several of our hotels in 2015.
The Chicago market was negatively impacted by a 53% decline in citywide room nights this quarter. Citywide room nights continue to decline in the market. However, we expect to benefit from strong in-house groups, which will result in improved performance at our Chicago hotels going forward. Despite the negative impacts of the January snowstorm and abundant new supply, our New York hotels experienced a positive 0.6% increase in RevPAR in first quarter, outperforming the STAR upper upscale market RevPAR decline of 2.1%. Our hotel managers in New York changed the strategy and began to add hotel transient business 3 months out, which help grow occupancy by 4.2% in a challenging rate environment. In addition, the New York Airport Marriott benefited from last year's renovation. Going forward, New York market is expected to remain challenged, as it continues to absorb new supply. And as a result, our hotels will likely underperform the portfolio in the second quarter. 
Moving to our international asset. These hotels had an impressive cost $1 RevPAR growth of 9.6% in the quarter. Latin America drove much of the international growth, with a constant dollar RevPAR increase of 22%, primarily from pre-Olympics test business in Rio.
The group booking pace remains strong for our hotels in Rio, due to the upcoming Olympics this summer. Although demand in Brazil could be impacted by the potential presidential continued weakness in oil and concerns over Zica. 
Shifting to our European joint venture. Paris attacks in Paris have negatively impacted our results with a RevPAR decline of 3.1% in constant euro this quarter. Negative results in Paris, Brussels and London were somewhat mitigated by positive results in Amsterdam, Berlin, Barcelona and Madrid. We expect continued weakness in Paris, Brussels and London, as travel alerts and warnings continues to be an issue. However, positive market fundamentals will exist in Europe, including the fact that supply remains slow at approximately 1% and the weak euro to the U.S. dollar could drive demand from the U.S. to Europe. 
Moving to our margins. Our comparable EBITDA margin expansion of 90 basis points is very impressive, especially considering the majority of the river per increase this quarter, was attributable to occupancy growth. Out this notable EBITDA margin growth is a result of our cost-saving initiatives, such as time and motion studies to improve productivity at many of our hotels as well as energy ROI projects. The third-party time and motion studies, combined with our internal initiatives resulted in sustainable productivity improvements of 17 basis points this quarter. The utility cost declined with a result of the mild winter and favorable gas and electric prices in addition to our properties beginning to realize the benefit of our cost savings energy ROI initiatives. We have invested in numerous projects over the past year from small projects such as the conversion to LED lighting and replacement of showerheads and major projects such as solar panels and steam to guess conversions in New York. In the first quarter, hotels that have completed energy ROI project decreased their utility cost by approximately 16.5%, which is 7 percentage points better than those hotels that did not have energy ROI project.
Given the positive margin result in the first quarter, we now expect 2016 comparable EBITDA margins to increase 25 to 65 basis points. We also expect approximately 29% to 30% of our total EBITDA to be generated in the second quarter. As discussed in our press release, during the first quarter, we repurchased 5.1 million shares for a total purchase price of $81 million. Since the inception of this share repurchase program in April 2015, we had now bought back 43.4 million shares of common stock for a total purchase price of approximately $758 million. We currently have $242 million of capacity remaining under the repurchase program. In addition, we repaid a regular first quarter cash dividend of $0.20 per share, which represent a yield of 5.1% on a current stock price. Given our strong operating outlook and significant free cash flow generation, we are committed to sustaining a meaningful dividend. In addition, based on the disposition plans for non-core assets, we have outlined and continue to execute on, we anticipate that asset sales will likely result in taxable gain, which could lead to a special dividend. While special dividends will vary and be one-time distribution, it should result in a meaningful return of capital to our stockholders.
Moving to one of the key pillars of strength and competitive advantage, our balance sheet. We had approximately $234 million of cash and $4 billion of debt. We continue to maintain a leverage ratio as calculated under our credit facility of 2.8x, which is approximately half that of our lodging peers and 1/3 that of our REIT peers. Subsequent to quarter end, we do on the credit facility to repay $100 billion mortgage loan secured by Hyatt Regency Westin hotels, bringing our encumbered properties to just 3 consolidated assets in Asia. Upon exiting the Asia markets, we will no longer have any consolidated assets that are encumbered by mortgage debt. 
Finally, as we mentioned in today's press release, due to the adoption of the new accounting announcement regarding consolidation, we deconsolidated the partnership that owns the Harbor Beach Marriott and recaptured the prior period to reflect the new treatment. As a result of the adoption, the operations of those property are no longer presented in other revenues on our income statement and instead reported as a net amount in equity and earnings affiliate.
Therefore, revenues for the first quarter 2016 and 2015, excluding rental income of $15 million earned by the partnership. However, the adoption does not affect net income, adjusted EBITDA or adjusted FFO. In summary, we are pleased with our results this quarter, as our assets are benefiting from aggressive asset management strategies and the tailwinds from our comprehensive capital program in 2015. This concludes our prepared remarks. We are now interested in answering any questions you may have. To ensure we have time to address questions from as many of you as possible, please limit yourself to one question and 1 follow-up.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks. And Ed, just wanted to ask you, our group revenues for the year still tracking about 6% in total. And just have you -- are you hearing any sort of change in Denver on corporation's willingness to send people, either out on the transient fron
componenttext: Okay. Thanks. And Ed, just wanted to ask you, our group revenues for the year still tracking about 6% in total. And just have you -- are you hearing any sort of change in Denver on corporation's willingness to send people, either out on the transient front or on the group front, given GDP was pretty disappointing yesterday and just kind of any color around that?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Overall, group revenues are trending well within 6%. I think we identified back in February that while we were running at roughly 6% of bookings in back in February, that we had assumed, because we had booked so many rooms in advance, that number wo
componenttext: Sure. Overall, group revenues are trending well within 6%. I think we identified back in February that while we were running at roughly 6% of bookings in back in February, that we had assumed, because we had booked so many rooms in advance, that number would likely decline over the course of the year. And in fact, we continue to believe that we continue to expect that our group revenue will fall within the range of overall RevPAR grow that we suggested. But likely towards the higher end of that range. As it relates to the corporate demand, we see special corporate drop, not every month, but in general. So there has been some because on that side, but as that -- if you look at corporate activity and translate that into group activity, our corporate business was actually up in the first quarter, which we viewed as a good sign. So I'm assuming that given that we had a 0.5% GDP growth in the first quarter, we will likely see some choppiness over the course of the year from the corporate sector. That will depend a lot on particular industries with financing one that seems to be a bit weaker. We are not necessarily -- we're certainly not seeing a wholesale trend across all corporations that they are cutting back.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I also would just like to clarify my first answer. So on Page 3 of the press release, if you add hotels under contract were $340 billion plus total sales, that obviously adding those 2 together would get to $461 million. If you do the same thing from our
componenttext: I also would just like to clarify my first answer. So on Page 3 of the press release, if you add hotels under contract were $340 billion plus total sales, that obviously adding those 2 together would get to $461 million. If you do the same thing from our prior quarters press release, you got 215 and so the additional proceeds from those 3 additional assets is really $246 million.

componenttext: So I just want to go back to quick comment that add made in the prepared remarks about Denmark is improving in the context of future asset sales. So my question here is, if you sort of characterize for us the composition of the buyer pool and which of those buyers are more debt dependent, more leveraged buyers than maybe more equitized buyers that have a different cost of capital, different time horizon and some of those considerations?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say right now, given that the rates are generally, with maybe an exception or 2 out of the acquisition market, that prove broadly defined groups of would be international capital, which seems to generally be less leveraged than it is. And the
componenttext: Yes. I would say right now, given that the rates are generally, with maybe an exception or 2 out of the acquisition market, that prove broadly defined groups of would be international capital, which seems to generally be less leveraged than it is. And then domestic capital, which I think tends to be real estate opportunity funds or operators or lines of financial partners. And that group does seem to be fairly sensitive to changes in that availability. So I would say by just to provide a little clarification around my comment, we are not saying that the debt markets are anywhere near as strong as they were last year. But we were seeing a very severe trend at the end of last year, beginning of this year as for the weakening in terms of terms and we're starting to year some signs that availability has improved a little bit in some cases spreads have come in a little bit. But again, not back to what it was. But at least a better trend than what we were feeling at the end of last year and first month of June this year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. That's helpful. And 1 follow up, is there any specific reason that share repurchase volume in first quarter decelerated somewhat meaningfully from the fourth quarter for instance? Or is it just the question of timing with the asset sales someth
componenttext: All right. That's helpful. And 1 follow up, is there any specific reason that share repurchase volume in first quarter decelerated somewhat meaningfully from the fourth quarter for instance? Or is it just the question of timing with the asset sales something else?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it was primarily related to the fact that asset sales had not yet closed. I mean, I think we said last quarter, we are comfortable right now with the environment that we're in, sort of stages of cycle where our leverage is. So in general, whilst n
componenttext: I think it was primarily related to the fact that asset sales had not yet closed. I mean, I think we said last quarter, we are comfortable right now with the environment that we're in, sort of stages of cycle where our leverage is. So in general, whilst not typically tied to our asset, the pace of our stock buyback activity will then relate with our ability to get asset sales done. So we're very encouraged by the overall pace of our activity. But I guess, I'd say we all have been around long enough to know that just because you're under contract with money at risk doesn't necessarily mean things are going to close. So we're sort of waiting get those closings completed before we fairily accelerate activity in the first quarter.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That your occupancy was stronger than it was in the first quarter in the context that industry occupancy was down. I mean, you obviously had renovation tailwind this year, as occupancy was down 70 basis points last year. But can you just give anymore colo
componenttext: That your occupancy was stronger than it was in the first quarter in the context that industry occupancy was down. I mean, you obviously had renovation tailwind this year, as occupancy was down 70 basis points last year. But can you just give anymore color on what's driving the occupancy and how to think about for the rest of the year? Thank you.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would agree with you that we certainly -- as we look at our result and compared them to what we saw an industry, we were very pleased to see that occupancy grow that we had. Now some chunk there was the fact there were rooms out of service. But I t
componenttext: Yes. I would agree with you that we certainly -- as we look at our result and compared them to what we saw an industry, we were very pleased to see that occupancy grow that we had. Now some chunk there was the fact there were rooms out of service. But I think largely reattributed to the fact that we had very good leisure demand, that's not in Florida, but pretty much all our the markets. And on a relative basis to the industry, I suspect our group demand was fairly strong too. So as we look through the rest of the year, given the fact that we've got a very strong group base, we're expecting -- I don't know that we would necessarily expect to see occupancy growth at the same rates as we have right now. We probably expect our RevPAR growth lean a little bit more towards rate growth going forward. Just because these next couple of quarters are months where we start with a really strong occupancy base. But we still expect to some gains in occupancy throughout the rest of the year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just my follow up, were you tempted at all to bring up the high end of your RevPAR guidance after this quarter? I mean you have helped America 3 to 5, you had stronger first quarter results and then, so you tempted at all to bring them up?
componenttext: And then just my follow up, were you tempted at all to bring up the high end of your RevPAR guidance after this quarter? I mean you have helped America 3 to 5, you had stronger first quarter results and then, so you tempted at all to bring them up?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well we're always tempted. But I guess, what I would say is that we were pleased with the way first quarter paid out. And I think that we took, what we thought is appropriately conservative perspective on RevPAR at the beginning of the year. Properties ar
componenttext: Well we're always tempted. But I guess, what I would say is that we were pleased with the way first quarter paid out. And I think that we took, what we thought is appropriately conservative perspective on RevPAR at the beginning of the year. Properties are more optimistic right now than we are. But on the other hand, what was demonstrated in first quarter GDP, the economy is not quite as robust as we all would like to see. So right now sitting where we are and feeling comfortable with where we are is the right answer.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: This is actually for Robyn. And to follow up on that question actually, you had mentioned that tougher comps in Q1 and Q4, it seems like Q1 came in slightly better than what you expected. Does that mean the shift impact on Q2 is a little bit less now, unless there is a shift within your guidance range? And then do you still expect you Q3 to be strongest in the group business?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think -- I don't know that we necessarily were commenting on tough comps in Q1. I think what I was saying in my prepared remarks and I'll elaborate a bit, is we have an exceptionally strong group booking in Q2 and Q3. And those are months, where
componenttext: Yes. So I think -- I don't know that we necessarily were commenting on tough comps in Q1. I think what I was saying in my prepared remarks and I'll elaborate a bit, is we have an exceptionally strong group booking in Q2 and Q3. And those are months, where we run at higher occupancy levels and it's what we have been seeing off late is in general when we were running at higher occupancy levels, that seems to be when we have the best opportunity to push rates. So that's why we feel very good about Q2 and Q3. And I would confirm what you said, which said today, what grew bookings for Q3 other strongest that we have throughout the entire year. Q4 is impacted by a number of things. I think what probably matters the most is the shift in the Jewish holiday, which are now impact October. And secondly, the fact that this year's election will probably most people want to pay attention to. And as the net of those 2 things we would expect less group business in the fourth quarter. And then finally, the other reason why we expect the fourth quarter to be a hair weaker is the fact that November and December -- second half of November and December tend to be lower occupancy months. And so what we experienced last year was it was more difficult to push rates in those months. We're expecting that same sort of a scenario will look like in this year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you. And if I may, a quick follow up, now we know that 2 of your larger hotel managers are combining. As an owner of those hotels, could you talk a bit general sentiment among owners, what this could mean? Whether in terms of loyalty programs,
componenttext: Okay. Thank you. And if I may, a quick follow up, now we know that 2 of your larger hotel managers are combining. As an owner of those hotels, could you talk a bit general sentiment among owners, what this could mean? Whether in terms of loyalty programs, occupancy sharing, just balancing of issues and opportunities? Thank you.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not going to try to speak for what other owners I would think. But I'd say from our perspective, we see both positives and benefits from this. I think what probably matters somewhere in the near term, assuming that they navigate and we expect th
componenttext: Well, I'm not going to try to speak for what other owners I would think. But I'd say from our perspective, we see both positives and benefits from this. I think what probably matters somewhere in the near term, assuming that they navigate and we expect they will, the challenges that exist around the integration. When we compare our cost structures, leaving out management fees between Starwood and Marriott. Right now Marriott -- if our Starwood hotels sat within the Marriott system, we would be able to save cost and improve margin. So we're hoping that they execute as we expect they will and that we ultimately get the benefit from that. I think that the challenge that the industry in general, has identified with the combination is that there will be a number of brands that will all sit beneath one-family, under 1 company and it will be important to be thoughtful about how to continue to distinguish those brands. We look forward to working with Marriott in order to make certain in cost-effective manner.

componenttextpreview: Sorry about that. I just had a question broadly on some of the hotel loyalty programs of booking direct. Has that impacted you positively or negatively? And then the other thing is, just on the pacing of asset sales over the next 12 months. What does the
componenttext: Sorry about that. I just had a question broadly on some of the hotel loyalty programs of booking direct. Has that impacted you positively or negatively? And then the other thing is, just on the pacing of asset sales over the next 12 months. What does the transaction environment look like, how you think about that next year or 2?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, it's little hard for us right now to get clear an indication on how some of the booking direct programs were impacting us. We do know that in an effort to drive more bookings directly to the less side, there were some -- there are some rate reducti
componenttext:
Steve, it's little hard for us right now to get clear an indication on how some of the booking direct programs were impacting us. We do know that in an effort to drive more bookings directly to the less side, there were some -- there are some rate reductions. And I would say that we -- I think that probably contributed to the less growth in our transient rate than what we might have normally seen in the past. So maybe from that standpoint it's slight negative. The flip side is of course, when you look at when gets to the bottom line, the cost of booking reservation directly with an operator significantly cheaper than if it were to happen through one of the OTAs. So we're certainly supportive of the overall strategy and we look forward to working with them to fine tune that as we move forward. As it relates to asset sales, I think that market is clearly not as robust as it was last year. We do, as I indicated in our prepared remarks, in addition to the assets that are under contract at this point that we identified in the press release, we have another $0.5 billion of activity that we're working hard on. And I would think we're making good progress on. At this point, we would expect to attempt to sell additional assets in the second half of the year. But a lot of that we depend upon how we see the market evolves over the course of the summer and what the outlook seems to be for the second half of the year for transaction activity.
So I feel relatively good about where we stand right now. I think we were -- we certainly one of the first in the industry to begin to look to sell assets. We didn't just come up with this idea and last 6 to 8 months. And I think we made great progress overall on the sale program. I'm hopeful that we will be able to keep going, but at this stage we have pretty take a little bit of a wait-and-see from the second half of the year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: And the next question is from Shaun Kelley with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: I just was wondering, you think in the prepared remarks you mentioned a little bit about some of the cost savings initiatives, I was wondering if you could talk a little bit more about where we are kind of in the timing of the rollout of those? Is there a lot more to come on this? Or are we relatively early on?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would guess, it's little hard to judge that in vacuum. But I think we're probably about halfway through. My guess is we have implemented more than half of those measures already. And I would also tell you that, we're not just because we're -- when I say
componenttext: I would guess, it's little hard to judge that in vacuum. But I think we're probably about halfway through. My guess is we have implemented more than half of those measures already. And I would also tell you that, we're not just because we're -- when I say we're halfway through, halfway through first call it 20 to 25 hotels but is that we're in the program on. We are operating on a scaled-down basis, but exhibiting the programs are some of our midsize attends. The there will not be a significant in the total dollar contract as they were in the larger hotels, simply because orders are smaller. But as we work our way through on getting benefit from this, a part of structure of this program is there is EBITDA cost saving cost-sharing relationship with the company that's helping us with that. And the part of -- the second year of benefit, we don't really taper anything. Consequently, there is a further opportunity for further pickup there. So I think we've certainly got a meaningful benefit. We would expect to continue to get more going forward.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. And my second follow-up question would be, taking back to the implications of Marriott and Starwood on the merger front. We had seen in the past around some of these prior integrations in with Marriott's rollout of Salesforce One some and s
componenttext: Great, thanks. And my second follow-up question would be, taking back to the implications of Marriott and Starwood on the merger front. We had seen in the past around some of these prior integrations in with Marriott's rollout of Salesforce One some and some challenges. That work themselves out of the time. But in sales organization specifically, can you guys are obviously very big group house for both of these brands. So could you talk a little bit about what do you think the sales impact might be, as they start to integrate some of the direct property levels since managers and all that. And that's something you think they are well-prepared for and they reach out to you on yet, or how do you think that's going to play out?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's probably too early for us to have any influence comment on that. We talk to them about some of that preliminary thoughts. And it certainly the issue that we're identifying and the concerns that you're identifying or the concerns that we have. Bu
componenttext: Yes. It's probably too early for us to have any influence comment on that. We talk to them about some of that preliminary thoughts. And it certainly the issue that we're identifying and the concerns that you're identifying or the concerns that we have. But specifically, how they are going to approach that. They have not given us any details on that yet. So I think I'm sure we will learn more as they move forward with consummating the merger, and then working towards the integration. But they're not at the point now where they have given us significant detail on that.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next will be Anthony Paul with Barclays.
componenttext: Next will be Anthony Paul with Barclays.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you comment on how group production for future periods trended, so far this year? Have you seen corporations pulled back at all on future group plans?
componenttext: Could you comment on how group production for future periods trended, so far this year? Have you seen corporations pulled back at all on future group plans?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally, the answer is that we've not seen corporations pulling back on the businesses they already had on the books. There were some markets where we saw some reduction in production compared to prior levels on smaller groups. But the larger -- we're n
componenttext: Generally, the answer is that we've not seen corporations pulling back on the businesses they already had on the books. There were some markets where we saw some reduction in production compared to prior levels on smaller groups. But the larger -- we're not seeing any -- certainly not seeing any trend of significant cancellation. We're not seeing a trend of significant attrition compared to the levels that would have might have been under contract. I was interested in food and beverage side, because that something that we're clearly watching this area. And we actually saw in the first quarter that our expense for our food and beverage spend per room per night was actually up nearly somewhere between 2.5% to 3%, which we view as favorable, especially given some of the overall economic headwinds.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, thanks. And we've heard some other REITs talk about better international inbound demanned trends across the balance of the year, are you seeing that? And where can that be most impactful for your portfolio?
componenttext: Got it, thanks. And we've heard some other REITs talk about better international inbound demanned trends across the balance of the year, are you seeing that? And where can that be most impactful for your portfolio?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We -- that is always a little tricky to get information that we fully trust on that area. Our sense was that we were still down in the first quarter on international travel. Now I would say, we were fairly encouraged by some of the arrivals we have been t
componenttext: We -- that is always a little tricky to get information that we fully trust on that area. Our sense was that we were still down in the first quarter on international travel. Now I would say, we were fairly encouraged by some of the arrivals we have been tracking which goes to February, which shows that Europe was up mid single-digits, China was up nearly 20%, Japan actually -- arrivals from Japan actually trended up, which was a nice change compared to what we saw last year. The 2 major inbound markets that we saw was down from a standpoint of air arrivals were Canada and Brazil, which were both down about 5%. So those were to markets where I think Brazil in probably economic situation. In Canada, I think that's really still being hit by the dollar. There is lots of discussion on actually sent GM's meeting, that there was a feeling that we may start to see international improving in summer, both because there is some better circumstances and some of those countries and also the fact that if the U.S. dollar doesn't continue to strengthen then the year-over-year change in the dollar is not a dramatic as what we anticipated in 2015. And that's -- we don't know whether or not that's going to happen.

componenttext: I'll ask you on the RevPAR guidance, which has been 3 to 4 since last time you reported and it's a tighter range obviously than maybe of the others. Can be read into that or maybe you've already grouped up a bit forest of the year? And then lot of this is baked in. And the question really is, do you have, I guess, adequate do you think you have a lot of upside to that number? Or is tighter range more reflection of having more group and maybe a little bit less variability?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think to answer the last part of your question first, I think that the group's activity that we have is very strong. And of course, as you know, it represents 37%, 38% of our overall business. So we always been significantly related to group than indust
componenttext: I think to answer the last part of your question first, I think that the group's activity that we have is very strong. And of course, as you know, it represents 37%, 38% of our overall business. So we always been significantly related to group than industry. I'm comfortable that with that pace, to the extent that we saw sort of a reacceleration in corporate transient that would not present a problem for us, because that would be just we reflected in a from a face. And we don't charge truncheon customer and the fact that that's one of one of the reasons we like to have very solid group base. I think you look very broad at why we are and others maybe where they are in terms of outlook, I think some of this is the fact that we have very diversified portfolio. So no market represents more than 11% of our EBITDA. And we've got some exposure to some lower supply margins, whether it's Phoenix, or maybe New Orleans, where we're looking at very strong growth this year out of those markets. The fact that we have a significant chunk of our portfolio in some key resort asset, I think also helps. So far was the trend we have been seeing this year and very strong leisure demand and we hope that to continue. And lastly, going back to the group point the large number of big group that we have, which contribute meaningfully to our profitability, they're all in good physical condition. We have invested significantly in them. And this is part of the cycle where they have opportunity to truly perform, both in the top and bottom. So as a stated in response to a question before, we continue to be conservative in our approach to guidance. But we feel very comfortable with where we are right now based on the information that we can evaluate.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. And just a quick follow up on the Marriott-Starwood merger, I think on paper the consensus is this is going to have a lot of long-term benefits. You guys, as you look out whether it's second half or maybe even next year, is there -- do you
componenttext: Great, thanks. And just a quick follow up on the Marriott-Starwood merger, I think on paper the consensus is this is going to have a lot of long-term benefits. You guys, as you look out whether it's second half or maybe even next year, is there -- do you -- was there any concern that there is any near-term slippage and maybe some of the larger competing brands try to take some of that business away temporarily, as Marriott and Starwood kind of sort some things out at the property level?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I would say is that we are certainly concerned, as anyone should be, that one large company represent portfolio emerging, you hope that, that merger happens and that integration happens, as effectively and as quickly as it can. We have no do
componenttext:
I guess, what I would say is that we are certainly concerned, as anyone should be, that one large company represent portfolio emerging, you hope that, that merger happens and that integration happens, as effectively and as quickly as it can. We have no doubt that our conversations with folks at Marriott, they are understanding importance of getting that right. Not just for us, but obviously for their own success. They are a talented group of people and one thing that Marriott has always been very good at execution. So I don't want to underestimate the challenges that they face, but I certainly think that they are aware of what they're heading into and doing the best they can to manage that process.
At the property -- some of this -- obviously that activity that happens above the property of the marketing side, but I don't want to give you sense that when you look at who is running the hotel on a day-to-day basis. Those folks are on site at the property and as we just -- again, we had a meeting with GMs a week ago, and it's clear that we are talking to both the Marriott in Starwood GM. They were very enthusiastic about this combination. It dramatic improvement of their opportunity. It will facilitate cooperation inappropriate manner in various markets, where we may have asset branded by under both companies. And I think in a lot of ways this is at the property level there, they're very fired up about what the future might bring. We are very focused on, but they're focused on what they're doing. But we're very much aligned with those property GM in terms of their activity. So again, we are certainly paying attention to this and we will be paying as closely as we can to making certain that every effort is being made to complete the integration as quickly really as they can get it done. But I suspect it will be okay.

componenttext: Ryan, I'm not sure. 90 basis point margin growth, 3.6% RevPAR growth was stronger than what we would've predicted. So we will be presently surprised as we move forward as well. Obviously at also mentioned that we expect to continue to have occupancy increases. But it will be more the RevPAR increase will be -- the RevPAR increase will be more balanced between rate and occupancy will be also helpful for us. But having said that, I don't know that we can sit here and count on utility cost are down 11% or more. So we'll see, I mean obviously we try to take into account the success that we had in the first quarter. And then we try to frankly my view for the rest of the year is slightly stronger than what it was just a quarter ago. So we try to take into account both of those things to come up with our new guidance of 25 basis points to 65 basis points.
