headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cody. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Before we begin, I'd like to remind everyone that many of the comments made today are considered to be forward-looking statements under federal
componenttext:
Thanks, Cody. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. 
Before we begin, I'd like to remind everyone that many of the comments made today are considered to be forward-looking statements under federal securities laws. As described in our filings with the SEC, these statements are subject to numerous risks and uncertainties that could cause future results to differ from those expressed, and we are not obligated to publicly update or revise these forward-looking statements.
In addition, on today's call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial information, such as FFO, adjusted EBITDA and comparable hotel results. You can find this information, together with reconciliation to the most directly comparable GAAP information, in today's earnings press release, in our 8-K filed with the SEC and the supplemental financial information on our website at hosthotels.com.
With me on the call today is Ed Walter, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Larson, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, Ed will provide a brief overview of our operations, and then will discuss our disposition and investment activities as well as the company's outlook for 2016. Greg will then provide greater detail on our second quarter performance by markets and discuss our margins and our balance sheet. Following their remarks, we will be available to respond to your questions.
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Ed.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gee. Good morning, everyone. As you may surmise from our results, it was an interesting quarter. While the operating environment across our industry was a bit choppy, we executed its plan on the dispositions we have previously referenced and added
componenttext:
Thanks, Gee. Good morning, everyone. As you may surmise from our results, it was an interesting quarter. While the operating environment across our industry was a bit choppy, we executed its plan on the dispositions we have previously referenced and added 2 more planned sales.
On the investment side, we acquired an irreplaceable ground lease, completed several major ROI investments and continued to repurchase our stock, all with a focus on creating value for our shareholders.
Let's start with the review of our results for the quarter. Adjusted EBITDA was $436 million for the quarter, which represents an increase of 3.3% over 2015 and was $782 million for the first half of the year, up 5.2%. Our adjusted FFO was $0.49 per share, an increase of 6.5% for the quarter, and $0.90 per share year-to-date, an increase of 11%. Overall, we are pleased with our bottom line EBITDA and FFO growth, which generally met or exceeded both our expectations in consensus, but we were disappointed that our room revenue growth was not stronger.
Our portfolio occupancy rate was 82.4%, an increase of 120 basis points compared to 2015. Constant currency RevPAR increased 2% for the quarter, as rate growth was difficult to generate. This RevPAR result was well below what we had anticipated in April.
We expected that we would benefit from strong group bookings, and that generally proved to be correct as group room nights increased 3% due to more than a 6.5% growth in our association segment and a very solid increase in corporate group. Our average group rate was up more than 2%, leading to a revenue improvement in group of more than 5%. While this certainly qualifies as a strong group quarter, it is worth noting that short-term group bookings declined to the 3-year average level, falling short of last year's accelerated pace, and we did experience a slight increase in cancellation. 
However, our transient segment fell meaningfully short of our expectation. Overall, transient room nights declined by 1% as corporate demand proved soft. This resulted in the hotels being forced to target price-sensitive leisure business and government business, with the latter segment up nearly 7%. The net result of this mix shift was our average transient rate fell slightly and transient revenues declined by slightly more than 1%. To help offset this transient softness, we increased our contract room nights by more than 20%. 
Declining international demand was also a drag on our transient demand. While difficult to precisely calculate, our international business, which represents slightly more than 10% of our total room nights, decreased approximately 7% in the quarter, further undermining our managers' efforts to drive transient rate.
Fortunately, a combination of strong group business and catering activity led to a 6.6% increase in banquet and AV revenue, which enabled the portfolio to achieve food and beverage revenue growth of 4.5%. 
Sales per group room night jumped more than 4%, which is one of our stronger quarters during this cycle and a good indication that groups are still prepared to spend freely on events.
Since nearly all of the F&B revenue growth came from the profitable catering business, the flow-through was quite strong at north of 70%. Other revenues at our comparable hotels grew 4.6%, as STAR revenues improved and we experienced an increase in attrition and cancellation fees, which are now running slightly ahead of what we experienced in the last 2 years. The flow-through in this area was also quite strong.
The solid flow-through in all segments of our business, combined with the benefits of various asset management initiatives and property investments, which Greg will detail -- discuss in more detail, led to comparable hotel EBITDA margin improvement of 65 basis points and EBITDA flow-through of more than 50%. As a result, comparable hotel EBITDA improved by roughly 5%. 
Year-to-date, our transient contract revenues have increased 3.3%, and our group revenues have improved by 3.1%. Comparable F&B revenues have increased 2.8%, driven by banquet and AV increase of 3.7%. Total comparable revenues have increased 2.9%, and comparable EBITDA margins have increased 75 basis points, leading to EBITDA improvement year-to-date of 5.7%. 
Turning to asset sales. As I referenced at the outset, we continue to make solid progress in our non-core asset disposition program. Closing the sales of the Atlanta Perimeter, Seattle Sea-Tac and Manhattan Beach Marriott as well as our 2 hotels located in Chile. The 3 U.S. assets represented older hotels located in airport or suburban locations that we felt would likely not grow cash flows over the long term at the rate of our overall portfolio. These sales, plus the 2 Christchurch, New Zealand hotels that we noted are under binding contract, bring our total sales for the year to roughly $500 million. It is worth noting that the EBITDA we are receiving in 2016 from these assets totaled $13 million, which should not be included in any of your 2017 estimates. 
While we continue to market several hotels, the buyer pool has declined in size, and pricing is not as attractive as when we commenced our sale program a few years ago. While we do expect to complete additional sales, we are only a seller if we can achieve acceptable pricing. During the last 3.5 years, we have sold more than $2.6 billion worth of hotels or nearly 15% of our consolidated and joint venture portfolio, which has enabled us to further refine our asset base and improve shareholder value. We are very comfortable with our overall progress on this front. 
Looking in investments. We are very pleased to have acquired the ground leases that sit beneath the Key Bridge Marriott. The second Marriott hotel to be constructed, this property is situated in Arlington, Virginia, at the end of the key bridge, which provides direct access to Georgetown and has spectacular views of Washington and all of the national monuments. We are in the midst of evaluating the various options for this site and hotel, which will clearly include alternate uses, and we look forward to providing updates on this exciting project in the future.
We have also completed the redevelopment of the Hyatt San Francisco Airport and the new 152,000-square-foot ballroom and exhibit hall complex at the San Diego Marquis. Both of these projects were completed on time and under budget. In addition to renovating all of the rooms and meeting space at the Hyatt, we also completed 9,000 square feet of new meeting space and totally transformed the atrium and F&B platform. Our group bookings for this hotel for the next 2 years are 35% ahead of the preconstruction levels. We also expect to have a very strong fall operating season.
At the San Diego Marquis, we have created the best combination of ballroom and exhibit space in the market, and customers are responding favorably, as bookings for the next 2 years have increased 40% compared to preconstruction levels.
As the second quarter proved that it's challenging to develop guidance during interesting times for the industry, the following factors provide some insight into our thinking about the second half of 2016. Based on consensus economic forecasts and general uncertainty around the U.S. election and international events, we expect that business profit growth and investment levels will not improve, which suggest the business transient demand will remain soft. Alternatively, continued strong employment and consumer confidence numbers suggest that leisure demand will remain solid. We expect international travel patterns will remain challenged, as demand from our -- from two of our largest international markets, Canada and Latin America, are impacted by both the strong U.S. dollar and weaker domestic economic growth.
Our group revenue pace for the remainder of the year is up more than 4%, with the majority of the increase occurring in the third quarter. While we would expect some moderation in the overall increase in our group segment, this compares favorably to the actual improvement we experienced in the first half of the year.
Q3 will benefit from the calendar shift of the Jewish holidays into October, while the fourth quarter will be hurt by both that shift and less travel expected during the week that includes Election Day.
The combination of all these factors suggests that RevPAR growth in the second half of the year will generally match what we experienced in Q2, with the third quarter considerably stronger and the fourth quarter somewhat weaker. As a result, we anticipate full year RevPAR will range from 2% to 3%. We expect F&B and other revenue growth will moderate slightly from the first half growth of 2.8% but still generate increased profits over 2015.
Combination of solid flow-through from all revenue-generating activities, continued benefit from our asset management efforts and the strong start to the year is expected to lead to comparable hotel EBITDA margin improvement from 40 to 70 basis points.
The net result of these factors is an estimated range for adjusted EBITDA of $1,435,000,000 to $1,465,000,000, which reflects a reduction at the midpoint of $7.5 million from our prior range. $1.5 million of this adjustment is tied to the sale of the 2 Christchurch hotels I referenced earlier, and the remainder is due to the reduction in our estimated top line growth, partially offset by improving margins. Our forecasted adjusted FFO range is $1.63 to $1.67.
With that, let me turn the call over to Greg Larson, our Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss our operating and financial performance in more detail.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. I'll start with specific commentary on performance within some of our major markets. RevPAR at our properties in Los Angeles continued to outperform the portfolio, with an impressive 9.1% increase in the second quarter. The results were d
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed. I'll start with specific commentary on performance within some of our major markets. 
RevPAR at our properties in Los Angeles continued to outperform the portfolio, with an impressive 9.1% increase in the second quarter. The results were driven by a 5% increase in ADR and a 3-percentage-point increase in occupancy to 84.2%. A strong group base, combined with solid transient demand at several of our hotels, drove the RevPAR increase, which exceeded the STAR upper upscale results by 140 basis points.
Looking forward, group booking pace in Los Angeles remains very strong, as the market is expected to host additional citywide during the remainder of this year. As a result, we expect continued outperformance from our Los Angeles properties.
Our 2 comparable hotels in Denver grew RevPAR 7.3% this quarter and outpaced the STAR upper upscale result by 260 basis points. Strong group and transient demand at the Westin primarily drove this outperformance. However, based on the softening of citywide pace and decreasing size of events, we expect our hotels in Denver to underperform the portfolio in the third quarter.
In Atlanta, RevPAR increased 6.6% for the quarter as a result of average rate growth of 3.2% and occupancy increase of 2.6 percentage points. Once again, a number of citywide events in the second quarter contributed to the outperformance. Based on group revenues on the books for the remainder of the year, we expect third quarter results to be better than the fourth quarter. 
RevPAR growth of 5.5% of our D.C. hotels significantly outperformed the STAR upper upscale RevPAR increase by 230 basis points. This was driven by both occupancy and rate this quarter, as occupancy increased 2.2 percentage points and average rate grew 2.9%. Several of our D.C. hotels benefited from planned renovations that we competed last year. Based on group booking pace for these hotels, we expect our properties in D.C. to achieve solid results in the third quarter.
Our Boston hotels RevPAR growth of 5% in the second quarter was driven by a rate increase of 2.2% and an occupancy improvement of 2.3 percentage points. Our managers' aggressive strategies to offer promotion and add high-end airline crews bolstered the RevPAR increase this quarter. These hotels also had an impressive increase in food and beverage revenues of 15.8%, entirely from the increase in the more profitable banquet and catering sales. Overall, our Boston properties are experiencing softer special corporate demand from the financial and consulting segment. As a result, we expect RevPAR to underperform the rest of our portfolio in the third quarter.
RevPAR at San Francisco hotels grew 2.8%, primarily driven by a rate increase of 2.9%. Overall transient demand softness and group room night declines due to the Moscone Center Convention construction led to demand weakness this quarter. However, strong catering business at several San Francisco hotels drove the outstanding banquet and catering revenue growth of over 33% this quarter. The expansion of the Moscone Convention Center will continue to negatively impact the San Francisco market for the remainder of 2016 and through 2017. Our San Francisco hotels will likely underperform our portfolio in the remaining quarters.
Moving to some challenged markets. New York RevPAR decreased 4.9% but outperformed the STAR upper upscale market RevPAR decline of 6%. Occupancy dropped slightly to 89.8%, and rate declined 4.8% in the second quarter. Supply continues to outpace demand, which is impacting our ability to drive rate. We have also witnessed the European travel and tour business declining due to the strong U.S. dollar. Based on our outlook for the market, we expect our hotels in New York to continue to have negative RevPAR for the remainder of the year.
As anticipated, our hotels in Florida underperformed the portfolio with a RevPAR decrease of 2.2% in the second quarter. Occupancy declined 2 percentage points, and rate increased 0.4%. The decline in RevPAR was due to softer leisure transient demand as well as increased group attrition and cancellations. 
On a positive note, group customers increased their food and beverage spend in the more profitable banquet and catering business by 15.8%. In addition, based on a strong group revenue pace for the third quarter, we expect RevPAR in Florida to outperform the portfolio in the third quarter.
RevPAR at our assets in San Diego grew slightly this quarter. Occupancy declined 2.9 percentage points, and rate increased 3.6%. Our hotels were negatively impacted by an 8.6% decline in transient revenues, resulting from fewer citywide compression nights from downtown. Despite the slow start in San Diego, we expect the hotels in this market to improve in the second half of 2016, as the city should benefit from an increase in citywide room nights for the remainder of the year, especially in the third quarter.
In addition, the new 152,000-square-foot Marriott Hall opened in June 2016 at the San Diego Marquis. 
Moving to our international assets. These hotels had a constant dollar RevPAR growth of 2.3% in the quarter. Latin America drove much of the international growth with a constant dollar RevPAR increase of 5%, primarily from continued pre-Olympics business in Rio. Due to the upcoming Olympics this summer, we expect Latin America to have a spectacular third quarter.
Shifting to our European joint venture. The portfolio was negatively impacted by a number of macro factors, including the lingering effects of the Paris attacks in Paris and Brussels and the political and economic uncertainty pre- and post-Brexit. All these led to a RevPAR decline of 1.3% in constant euro [ph] this quarter. As expected, our hotels in Paris, London and Brussels significantly underperformed the portfolio, while our hotels in Spain, Stockholm and Amsterdam outperformed. We expect the challenges that I described for our hotels in Paris, London and Brussels will continue into the third quarter.
Moving to our profitability. Our comparable EBITDA margin expansion of 65 basis points in an environment with 2% RevPAR growth is very impressive. This notable EBITDA margin growth is the result of decreases in our utility and insurance expenses as well as our continued cost saving initiatives. Utility costs decreased almost 6%, and insurance expense decreased 5.5% in the quarter. Utility costs continued to decline in the second quarter due to favorable gas and electric prices as well as the benefits from our cost saving energy ROI initiatives.
As we have said previously, we have invested in numerous energy projects over the last year, ranging from small to major projects, which are favorably impacting our utility cost. Further, in June, we completed our annual negotiation of our insurance contracts and lowered rates for another year. Therefore, we expect our insurance expense to continue to decrease for the remainder of the year and through the first half of 2017.
Over the last 2 years, we have focused on improving productivity at our hotels by initiating time and motion studies at our largest hotels. These studies resulted in hotel managers establishing tighter labor model standards and the use of improved and expanded forecasting tools, allowing managers to effectively schedule to demand and minimize excess staffing.
For example, many of our housekeeping departments are now using an automated system integrated with a property management system to prioritize housekeeping room assignments using a WiFi-enabled device. The system saves on time and labor expense while getting guests in the rooms faster. Total hourly productivity at our hotels that have implemented the recommendations improved over 400 basis points more than those hotels that have not yet conducted a time and motion study. 
For all the discussion of technology as a disruptor in the lodging space, we are seeing real cost saving benefits of technology in our industry and our properties. In addition, sustainability initiatives that provide guests with the option to forgo housekeeping services in exchange for reward points, like Marriott's Your Room. Your Choice and Starwood's Make A Green Choice program, are also positively impacting expenses.
Given the positive margin results in the first half of 2016, we now expect full year comparable EBITDA margins to increase 40 to 70 basis points. We also expect approximately 22.5% to 23% of our total and adjusted EBITDA to be generated in the third quarter.
As disclosed in our press release, during the second quarter, we repurchased 5.2 million shares at an average price of $15.39, for a total purchase price of $81 million. Since the inception of our share repurchase program in April 2015, we have bought back 48.6 million shares of common stock for a total purchase price of approximately $838 million. We currently have $162 million of capacity remaining under the repurchase program.
In addition, we paid a regular second quarter cash dividend at $0.20 per share, which represents a yield over 4.5% on the current stock price. We continue to operate from a position of financial strength and flexibility and believe we have one of the best balance sheets in the lodging REIT and overall REIT space. Importantly, we view this as a key competitive and strategic advantage and expect to continue benefiting from it going forward.
We ended the second quarter with approximately $266 million of cash, $739 million of available capacity under our revolving credit facility and $3.7 billion of debt. We improved our leverage ratio as calculated under our credit facility to 2.6x.
During the quarter, we repaid the $100 million mortgage loan secured by the Hyatt Regency Reston hotel. We also think it is important to note that 95 of our hotels, which represent 99% of our revenues, are unencumbered by mortgage debt.
In summary, we are pleased with our results this quarter, as the profitability of our assets continues to improve as a result of our aggressive asset management strategies in what continues to be a competitive market environment.
This concludes our prepared remarks. We are now interested in answering any questions you may have. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll now take our first question from Smedes Rose with Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll now take our first question from Smedes Rose with Citi.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, I wanted to ask you maybe a little bit more -- if you could share a little more color on the cancellations that you saw in the quarter and maybe through the balance of the year. It sounds like it was a little bit elevated in Florida. Do you see this a
componenttext: Ed, I wanted to ask you maybe a little bit more -- if you could share a little more color on the cancellations that you saw in the quarter and maybe through the balance of the year. It sounds like it was a little bit elevated in Florida. Do you see this as economic concerns? Is it Zika concerns? Is it Florida-related? Maybe just a little more color around that would be good.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Smedes, that's a great question because we spent a fair amount of time talking to the operators to get a feeling for that. As best as we can tell, it seems like most of the cancellations were what I would describe as situational. So they were -- in s
componenttext: Yes, Smedes, that's a great question because we spent a fair amount of time talking to the operators to get a feeling for that. As best as we can tell, it seems like most of the cancellations were what I would describe as situational. So they were -- in some cases, there might have been a change around a product, and so there was -- around the timing of a product launch. But in other cases, it sounded as if certain companies were just trying to be thoughtful about the level of expense that they were incurring in 2016, and I attribute that in part to some of the weaker corporate profit numbers that we've seen. So it did feel as if it was thematic. It seemed like it was specific to the individual companies that had cancellations. But I took some comfort from -- was the fact that the cancellations that we're seeing were generally focused on 2016. We're not necessarily seeing any increase in cancellations related to 2017. So that tells me that it's a little bit more of a short-term orientation, and people were not necessarily backing away from their plans to have events down the road.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Smedes, as I mentioned in my comments, we actually expect Q3 to be pretty strong for our Florida hotel.
componenttext: And, Smedes, as I mentioned in my comments, we actually expect Q3 to be pretty strong for our Florida hotel.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I mean, can you share the group pace -- revenue pace for 2017 at this point?
componenttext: Okay. And then, I mean, can you share the group pace -- revenue pace for 2017 at this point?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say it's up low single digits.
componenttext: I'd say it's up low single digits.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now move on to our next question from Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll now move on to our next question from Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of questions. Just the first one, I want to touch on the ground lease purchase. So was that something that was just opportunistic when the lease was expiring? Or what was -- just give us a little more color about the origin of that opportunity
componenttext: So a couple of questions. Just the first one, I want to touch on the ground lease purchase. So was that something that was just opportunistic when the lease was expiring? Or what was -- just give us a little more color about the origin of that opportunity. And I know you said you'd give details later on as to what you actually do with the property, but could you give us a hint -- any hints ahead of time there?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The -- I guess, obviously, this is a hotel that's been in our company for a long period of time. For those of you that know Washington, D.C., you probably know the hotel because you've driven by it a number of times on the G.W. Parkway. It really is
componenttext: Yes. The -- I guess, obviously, this is a hotel that's been in our company for a long period of time. For those of you that know Washington, D.C., you probably know the hotel because you've driven by it a number of times on the G.W. Parkway. It really is a great location on the edge of Georgetown, and the views from the rooms are spectacular because you're looking right down the mall at all the monuments. This was a land lease situation from the time the hotel was built. We have spent off and on the last 10 years negotiating with the owners of the  foundation that owned the property in an effort to try to get complete control of the property. So, I guess, I would say it was opportunistic in the sense that we finally had -- they were finally motivated to sell, and we finally had the opportunity to buy. We had the right of first refusal, which is essentially what we exercised on. So it was sort of -- we had -- if we were going to buy it, we needed to do it now. And I think as it relates to the opportunities for the property, there's -- we believe -- we haven't had extensive conversations with local officials yet, but we are fairly comfortable in believing that there is excess density associated with the site. So we're in a process now that we know we have control of the property. We're looking at a range of options that would include the complete scraping of the asset and a complete redevelopment of the entire parcel, which would involve for us probably selling off a number of those parcels to other parties. We are also potentially redeveloping a part of the hotel and then selling off portions of the hotel to third parties to develop either residential or office. So it wasn't -- we're really in the midst of the effort right now to understand how to maximize the value. There is a lot of local interest in the site, local and national interest, for that matter, because of just the superb positioning of the property. So we'll provide more of an update going forward as we have a clear idea about how to maximize value for this property.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean, generally, what sort of a return would you expect on some -- on a big project like this with multiple options?
componenttext: Okay. I mean, generally, what sort of a return would you expect on some -- on a big project like this with multiple options?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I'd say is it would -- it should -- some of that depends upon how we pursue it. I think it's early to try to quote what the value of the underlying land might be. A lot of that is going to relate to what approach do we ultimately take.
componenttext: I guess, what I'd say is it would -- it should -- some of that depends upon how we pursue it. I think it's early to try to quote what the value of the underlying land might be. A lot of that is going to relate to what approach do we ultimately take.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. I'll move to the next question. So my last question here is, just in terms of the non-same-store pool of assets, one of the big selling points, I guess, for Host in 2016 was it's a renovation tailwind story, which is an opposition to what
componenttext: Okay. All right. I'll move to the next question. So my last question here is, just in terms of the non-same-store pool of assets, one of the big selling points, I guess, for Host in 2016 was it's a renovation tailwind story, which is an opposition to what happened last year. So I'm curious, are the renovated projects sort of open? Or are they performing in line with underwriting? Are you generating the ADR lift in the overall returns you're expecting? Just as we sort of compare it to the same-store 2% RevPAR number for the quarter, for instance.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Here's what I would say with this. I think overall, we're still expecting that the 4 assets that we had talked about earlier in the year are going to generate the improvement in EBITDA that we had forecasted. I would also tell you that in terms of looking
componenttext: Here's what I would say with this. I think overall, we're still expecting that the 4 assets that we had talked about earlier in the year are going to generate the improvement in EBITDA that we had forecasted. I would also tell you that in terms of looking at how we're going to get to that number, the ramp-up in the first quarter, call it, first 4 or 5 months of the year, was probably a bit slower lower than what we expected. But at this point, we're generally in line with our expectations for where we expected to be with the properties. And then I think we feel fairly confident about how that's going to the play out for this year. And then we also expect that there'll be an opportunity for incremental lift in 2017, simply because in each instance, 3 of the 4 properties, 1 in San Francisco, Camby in Phoenix and The Logan in Philadelphia, all of those, because they were closed, were essentially new hotels opening up in the beginning of this year. And so they did not immediately jump to stabilize operating levels in the beginning of that year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Rich, the only thing I would add is if you're looking at our press release, you can see our non-comp hotels actually had a decline in RevPAR for the quarter, and that was primarily due to 2 big hotels. As you know, Denver Tech is under renovation rig
componenttext: And, Rich, the only thing I would add is if you're looking at our press release, you can see our non-comp hotels actually had a decline in RevPAR for the quarter, and that was primarily due to 2 big hotels. As you know, Denver Tech is under renovation right now, and that's a fairly large hotel with over 600 rooms. And the RevPAR for that hotel is down over 30%. And in the Hyatt San Francisco, again, another big hotel, 789 rooms, that hotel also had a RevPAR decline of 18%. So those 2 hotels are really driving the negative RevPAR in the non-comp hotels right now.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You'll now take the next question from Anthony Powell with Barclays.
componenttext: You'll now take the next question from Anthony Powell with Barclays.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question on pricing in leisure transient side. Have you seen any impact, the downside from some of the member discounts we're seeing from the brand companies on your ability to drive rate?
componenttext: I had a question on pricing in leisure transient side. Have you seen any impact, the downside from some of the member discounts we're seeing from the brand companies on your ability to drive rate?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that the discount that the brands are offering to reward members is having a slight negative impact on RevPAR. My guess is, is that I think Arne was quoted yesterday in saying it was about 30 to 40 basis points, and based on our conversations with
componenttext: I think that the discount that the brands are offering to reward members is having a slight negative impact on RevPAR. My guess is, is that I think Arne was quoted yesterday in saying it was about 30 to 40 basis points, and based on our conversations with them and others, that seems to be about right. This certainly -- initially right now, we're bearing some hit for the implementation of those programs. I think the expectation in the long run though is that they will accomplish share shift. And obviously, the cost of a reservation booked through the brand website is considerably less than what we might book through other third-party alternatives.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And moving on to asset sales. I think at the beginning of the year, you were targeting $1 billion in sales. You have $500 million now. Is it the case that you're essentially done with the asset sales or just being opportunistic? And how does that o
componenttext: Right. And moving on to asset sales. I think at the beginning of the year, you were targeting $1 billion in sales. You have $500 million now. Is it the case that you're essentially done with the asset sales or just being opportunistic? And how does that outlook impact your share repurchase activity for the rest of the year?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes, I would say that -- I would say, one, we're not done with asset sales. I -- we are still working on a number of transactions and would hope to complete some more. I also would probably say right now that at this stage, I wouldn't necessarily b
componenttext: Right. Yes, I would say that -- I would say, one, we're not done with asset sales. I -- we are still working on a number of transactions and would hope to complete some more. I also would probably say right now that at this stage, I wouldn't necessarily be expecting to complete a $1 billion number within calendar year 2016 because I think some of the -- one of the sales that I think ultimately may prove -- will prove to be more likely would be the sales of Melbourne Hilton. But I have a feeling at this point that, that sale is likely to be dragged into 2017 as opposed to be completed this year. I think as I said in our prepared remarks, we're very happy with the overall sale program that we've implemented over the last 3.5 years. We would like to continue to sell assets in part because we'd love to use the proceeds and contracts of our stock buyback program, but we do want to make certain that we're getting pricing that we think makes sense. Now if you look at the sales that we've announced so far this year, without even taking into account the capital spending that might have been required as part of the transition of that property, say, to a franchise status, we were in the mid-7s in terms of a cap rate on those sales, which frankly compares very favorably to where we're trading as a company. And I if I looked at the relative quality of what we were selling compared to what we're retaining, that relationship looks even more attractive.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just following up on that. So if there aren't materially more asset sales to stop buyback this year, or would you just use cash proceeds or cash flow to fund share buybacks?
componenttext: Got it. And just following up on that. So if there aren't materially more asset sales to stop buyback this year, or would you just use cash proceeds or cash flow to fund share buybacks?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have -- with the sales that we've completed, we do have, I would say, some extra cash that could be invested in the stock buyback. Some of that will obviously get tied into what our ultimate dividend requirement is going to be. And I think we'r
componenttext: I think we have -- with the sales that we've completed, we do have, I would say, some extra cash that could be invested in the stock buyback. Some of that will obviously get tied into what our ultimate dividend requirement is going to be. And I think we're still interested in buying back stock. Obviously, as you look at the price that we've paid in this most recent quarter, part of what governs our activity in the stock is where the stock price is, but I think we're still open to additional stock repurchase.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Jeff Donnelly with Wells Fargo.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I maybe could just stick with the question on disposition for a moment. Ed, I'm just curious, I mean, assuming markets are cooperative, is there a particular goal that you have in mind, I mean, where you'd like to be with the portfolio, looking beyond
componenttext: If I maybe could just stick with the question on disposition for a moment. Ed, I'm just curious, I mean, assuming markets are cooperative, is there a particular goal that you have in mind, I mean, where you'd like to be with the portfolio, looking beyond just the sales you're contemplating for 2016? I wasn't sure if you had a sort of number of assets, number of markets or other sort of metrics that shape how you're thinking about where you'd like to bring the portfolio.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeff, it's a good question. I would tell you that within -- with maybe just a few exceptions, I would say that we have sold the bulk of the hotels that we would have started -- when we looked at the -- start to look at commencing a sale program 3 or 4 yea
componenttext: Jeff, it's a good question. I would tell you that within -- with maybe just a few exceptions, I would say that we have sold the bulk of the hotels that we would have started -- when we looked at the -- start to look at commencing a sale program 3 or 4 years ago. We sold the bulk of the hotels that we felt we were either quality reasons, capital reasons or likely underperformance in the market reasons. We sold the bulk of the hotels that we'd like to do. There are a couple more that I think we would like to sell, where we would view them as perhaps detractors in the long run from our likely performance, but not that many. I mean, I'm really talking about a small handful of hotels. So I'd say that it ultimately -- moving past, perhaps, selling that handful of hotels, it really just comes down to a function of pricing. And in a market that seems to be a little less robust than where it had been, I'd probably say, at this moment, I'm not as optimistic that we're necessarily going to be selling a lot of additional hotels unless we see pricing start to improve.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in other words, it's not $500 million down and $3 billion to go or something like that?
componenttext: So in other words, it's not $500 million down and $3 billion to go or something like that?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, definitely not, at least not on our current perspective.
componenttext: No, definitely not, at least not on our current perspective.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just sticking on the sales question, can you maybe just give us a little more color about what you've learned from the marketplace with dispositions in terms of how buyers are underwriting? Are they kind of looking at it on a per key basis? Is it sort
componenttext: And just sticking on the sales question, can you maybe just give us a little more color about what you've learned from the marketplace with dispositions in terms of how buyers are underwriting? Are they kind of looking at it on a per key basis? Is it sort of cash flow yields? Or is it sort of an IRR-driven buyer? And, I guess, if I could, I just had one other question on just group trends.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's a little bit dependent on the type of buyer that you're dealing with. So the international buyers tend to be looking more at long-term storage of value and tend to -- what we have found in our conversations with them, trend towards the h
componenttext: Yes, I think it's a little bit dependent on the type of buyer that you're dealing with. So the international buyers tend to be looking more at long-term storage of value and tend to -- what we have found in our conversations with them, trend towards the higher-quality assets. The financial buyers that are -- probably are using more leverage than what we might necessarily use, it seems to me that they're primarily focused on a cash flow stream that will generate a fairly attractive rate of return and provide some cushioning against what might happen later in this cycle, and they're trying to rely less on a growth in the value of the asset in terms of either certainly cap rate compression or just a significant increase in value down the road. So it seems to be it's much more around current cash flow in terms of a driver for them.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the question I just have in group and I'll yield the floor is that just earlier in the year, I think you guys had shared measures on group attrition and cancellations and just any of your bookings that maybe they weren't necessarily moving in the righ
componenttext: And the question I just have in group and I'll yield the floor is that just earlier in the year, I think you guys had shared measures on group attrition and cancellations and just any of your bookings that maybe they weren't necessarily moving in the right direction. Can you just talk about how those trends have moved from Q1 and into Q2 and maybe how that shapes your thinking for next year? As we roll forward, and yes, I think you gave a metric earlier in the call about your group pace being up single digits in 2017, do you recall what that same metric was last year looking at '16?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me try to address the first part of your question, then come back to that. So I think what  we indicated earlier in the year was that we were -- certainly had very strong group bookings. And I think at the end of the first quarter, as we look thr
componenttext: Yes, let me try to address the first part of your question, then come back to that. So I think what  we indicated earlier in the year was that we were -- certainly had very strong group bookings. And I think at the end of the first quarter, as we look through the rest of the year, we thought we were up I think it was around 5% to 6%. And what we said at the time was because we were running so far ahead in terms of the prior year in terms of group bookings, that, to some degree, there was just not as many nights and rooms that were still capable being sold in a lot of those hotels for group. And so we were expecting that what would happen over the course of the year is that group would still be very strong, but that it would generally fall to a level of production on from a revenue perspective that was consistent with the overall range of RevPAR guidance that we were providing at that point in time. So we were suggesting that, yes, we might be up 5% to 6% right now, but given at that point in time we were talking 3% to 4% in terms of RevPAR, we expected that group revenues would ultimately moderate and be more in line with that level. If I were to look out today, looking out for the rest of the year, I would say that what we generally were expecting was going to happen with group, which was that the lead that we had over the prior year would probably condense a bit, and that has happened. I think we're still pretty confident about group for the second half of the year. It -- I might on the margin say, because we've seen a little bit of incremental weakness in short-term group bookings, that we're a hair less confident in terms of how group compares to what we thought in April. So, by and large, when we look at our booking pace for the remainder of the year and calibrate them with expectations of what we actually expect to generate, we still feel pretty good about the group -- our group business. When we look into next year, I would say that we're probably -- we are running a little bit behind -- our growth for '17 is not as strong as our growth for '16. Our growth for '16, thinking back to calendar '15, was sort of mid-single digit for most of 2015. So we are behind in terms of a rate of growth, but, of course, remember, we've been saying for a while, including a lot of last year, that the group bookings for 2016 were quite strong. We're still saying that our group bookings for 2017 are better than our group bookings for 2016. So we're having -- we're slated to have a better year for group in terms of absolute amount of group nights and absolute group revenues in 2017, but that rate of improvement right now would be slightly lower than what we were forecasting 1 year ago for 2016.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Ryan Meliker with Canaccord Genuity.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Ryan Meliker with Canaccord Genuity.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to talk a little bit about the guidance reduction for the back half of the year. You gave some good color on group pace and the idea that you're expecting transient trends to slow -- or not slow but remain soft, I guess. Can you give us some
componenttext: I just wanted to talk a little bit about the guidance reduction for the back half of the year. You gave some good color on group pace and the idea that you're expecting transient trends to slow -- or not slow but remain soft, I guess. Can you give us some color on kind of what type of macro outlook? I'm assuming you have some type of macro model that you use to help drive kind of transient RevPAR demand trends for the back half of the year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say that what we have found over the years was the best indicator for what was going to happen to corporate transient is generally tied to what's happening in terms of business investment. The investment activity is higher. Travel seems to b
componenttext: Sure. I would say that what we have found over the years was the best indicator for what was going to happen to corporate transient is generally tied to what's happening in terms of business investment. The investment activity is higher. Travel seems to be -- business transient seems to be stronger. And while I was -- didn't have much time to absorb the GDP report that came out earlier this morning, I did note that business investment was off in the second quarter, and I think it might have even been off more than 2%. So I wouldn't say that our approach to this is so scientific that we calibrated what our expectation for business investment would be for the second half of the year. I think that would presume too much. But we did assume, based on the data that we've been seeing and the outlook that we would see from people that spend their time forecasting that, is it generally was expected to be weaker. So until that changes, we assume that corporate travel will probably still -- it will still be there, but the growth in the demand from that side will not be as strong as it might have been in the past. And that's one of the reasons why as we look at the transient side of our business -- and I think it's clear from my comments, is that, that's the part of our business that disappointed us in Q2. That's the part of our business that we think is weaker in the second half of the year. We're assuming that we will see weakness in corporate demand, consequently push us more towards some of the more price-sensitive segments in leisure discount business. And that's what underlies the fact that we're adjusting our RevPAR guidance down for the second half of the year and obviously for the full year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that makes sense. So just to make sure I understand it correctly, it sounds like you're assuming that the soft business investment spend dynamics that we've seen in the first half of the year really persist through the back half of the year. Is th
componenttext: I think that makes sense. So just to make sure I understand it correctly, it sounds like you're assuming that the soft business investment spend dynamics that we've seen in the first half of the year really persist through the back half of the year. Is that correct?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That is correct. That is correct.
componenttext: That is correct. That is correct.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So no acceleration or deceleration necessarily?
componenttext: Okay. So no acceleration or deceleration necessarily?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. I would say a few words. If you were trying to look at what might change this dynamic a little bit and lead to stronger growth, it would be improvement in corporate investment, which could then turn around. Corporate travel reacts very quickly, b
componenttext: Correct. I would say a few words. If you were trying to look at what might change this dynamic a little bit and lead to stronger growth, it would be improvement in corporate investment, which could then turn around. Corporate travel reacts very quickly, both down and up. So to the extent that the investment side of their business starts to -- their perspective changes, they get more optimistic. That's the one place for upside, too.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just 1 quick follow-up. Greg, you had mentioned that you're expecting San Francisco to be a little softer in the back half of the year. I'm wondering if you guys have tried to quantify the impact to the Moscone Center renova
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just 1 quick follow-up. Greg, you had mentioned that you're expecting San Francisco to be a little softer in the back half of the year. I'm wondering if you guys have tried to quantify the impact to the Moscone Center renovation, what you think that's going to do in 4Q and then next year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, look, it's certainly going to impact the second half of this year and certainly next year. But I don't have an exact number for you. But we are -- within our guidance that we gave today for our portfolio, 2% to 3% RevPAR growth, we're actually mod
componenttext: I mean, look, it's certainly going to impact the second half of this year and certainly next year. But I don't have an exact number for you. But we are -- within our guidance that we gave today for our portfolio, 2% to 3% RevPAR growth, we're actually modeling San Francisco to have a slight -- to be slightly negative in the second half of the year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And is it reasonable for us to assume it will be slightly negative again next year?
componenttext: Okay. And is it reasonable for us to assume it will be slightly negative again next year?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I expect it to be negative. I think it's awfully early right now to try to provide an outlook relative to '17. But what I can tell you that -- at least as a concern, is that when we were looking at our bookings for next year, one of the markets that was,
componenttext: I expect it to be negative. I think it's awfully early right now to try to provide an outlook relative to '17. But what I can tell you that -- at least as a concern, is that when we were looking at our bookings for next year, one of the markets that was, in a sense, the weakest in terms of bookings for 2017 was San Francisco. So there is clearly going to be some impact from the closing of the construction activity around the convention center.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll now take our next question from Chris Woronka with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll now take our next question from Chris Woronka with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was hoping maybe we could drill down a little bit on the rates. And I know that in 2Q, and I think even in 1Q, your mix shifting had a lot to do with it. And so I'm trying to get a sense for how much of the rate underperformance may be relative to your
componenttext: I was hoping maybe we could drill down a little bit on the rates. And I know that in 2Q, and I think even in 1Q, your mix shifting had a lot to do with it. And so I'm trying to get a sense for how much of the rate underperformance may be relative to your expectations is just mix. And how much of it is kind of real-time softening on the transient side?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say it's a combination of both. So if I look across our different segments, I would say that in the lower-priced segments, government or in some of our discount segments, we actually had fairly strong rate growth. So, for instance, our government busi
componenttext: I'd say it's a combination of both. So if I look across our different segments, I would say that in the lower-priced segments, government or in some of our discount segments, we actually had fairly strong rate growth. So, for instance, our government business, from a rate perspective, was up 4.4%, and our discount business was up about 3%. So we saw a good jump in those segments, where we saw -- we did see at our highest-priced business in retail and some of the -- that type -- that segment, we did see some rate decline. So I would tell you, at the end of the day, it's a combination of both. The good news is, is the segment we did more, we had growth and also had higher rates. So that's positive. The downside is, is that the actual rate of business -- the rate that we charge those customers tends to be lower than the rate that we would charge our most expensive retail customers. So it was a combination of, at the top level, some weakness in rate -- some negative rate growth, combined with a lot of rate shift -- mix shift.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then also wanted to ask, it seems to be, with all the uncertainty out there, the trend is kind of lower shorter booking windows. Do you -- are you guys working with the brands? Do you think there -- could this be more of a longer-term tre
componenttext: Okay, great. And then also wanted to ask, it seems to be, with all the uncertainty out there, the trend is kind of lower shorter booking windows. Do you -- are you guys working with the brands? Do you think there -- could this be more of a longer-term trend? And do you think the brands are kind of on top of it? And are you working with them to maybe look at changes in policies or things like that?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we are necessarily seeing right now that the booking window is shorter. I mean -- I -- we're -- we've -- as we've reached higher occupancy levels, we've generally seen the booking window extended. And we're still seeing -- even looking o
componenttext: I don't know that we are necessarily seeing right now that the booking window is shorter. I mean -- I -- we're -- we've -- as we've reached higher occupancy levels, we've generally seen the booking window extended. And we're still seeing -- even looking out to 2018, we're still seeing good growth in our group business. So I don't know that we would necessarily sit here and say that we think the window has shortened so far this year.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So -- all right. Let's get on with it. I did stir the pot. So the question is, if you've seen deceleration in corporate investment, through these cycles, have you ever seen it reaccelerate once you see these trends in group bookings begin to soften?
componenttext: So -- all right. Let's get on with it. I did stir the pot. So the question is, if you've seen deceleration in corporate investment, through these cycles, have you ever seen it reaccelerate once you see these trends in group bookings begin to soften?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Harry, that's a good question. I'm trying to think back. The last -- certainly, the last 2 downturns, my guess is that your general assumption is that once it rolled over, it continued to head down. Now what's different though is that in both of those las
componenttext: Harry, that's a good question. I'm trying to think back. The last -- certainly, the last 2 downturns, my guess is that your general assumption is that once it rolled over, it continued to head down. Now what's different though is that in both of those last 2 cycles in 2001, it has started to go negative in the beginning of the year, and then, obviously, we had the attack on 9/11, followed by SARS, followed by the war. So we sort of had -- once things went a little south, I don't know that we necessarily got a chance to see how the economic environment was going to play out in kind of -- in this context. There was a lot of other events that intervened to create a problem. And, of course, the financial recession had somewhat of a similar tempo to it. So coming back to what we might expect this time, I do think that -- if you look at what the Fed just said in what they came out with earlier this week, I don't know that they're necessarily acting or speaking in the context of thinking that the economy is about to roll over. I have a feeling, just sort of looking at this through my own lens, is that part of what corporate America is trying to figure out is, what does Brexit mean? What does this unsettled -- these attacks that have happened across the world. Who in the world is going to be the next President of the United States? And what exactly -- what are they -- what policies are they going to pursue? So I can't -- sort of the last thing I'm going to try to do is predict the future in terms of economics. But I could look at this and say that if the Fed is right that the underlying economy is actually fairly healthy, then if companies had a different perspective about some of these issues that I think do affect people's willingness to invest, I think there is an opportunity to see corporate investment improve. I believe that the consensus forecast for next year does call for some slight improvement in business investment, not robust but some slight improvement. So not that they've necessarily been right at all through this cycle, but if they were right, then that might offer an opportunity to see some improvements. Checking my data on that. The most recent blue chip consensus talks about the corporate investment next year at 3.1%. So that was down a little bit from where it had been the prior quarter but still pretty positive. So I think that will be the -- in our mind, based on -- given that we see that being a fairly influential indicator for us, we'll have to see how that plays out.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then my second question is, what do you need to see to take the base dividend up?
componenttext: And then my second question is, what do you need to see to take the base dividend up?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally, what we've done is tie our dividend to our taxable income. So one of the biggest drivers there would be, we would need to see our taxable income continue to increase. We have generated incremental taxable income as a result of our asset sales.
componenttext: Generally, what we've done is tie our dividend to our taxable income. So one of the biggest drivers there would be, we would need to see our taxable income continue to increase. We have generated incremental taxable income as a result of our asset sales. And so one of the things we'll provide more clarity on I would expect at our next conference call is the degree to which we would have a special dividend. I would say that, certainly, in terms of thinking about the dividend long term, we are certainly focused on having a dividend set at a level that we're comfortable in maintaining, even to the extent we might go through a period of weakness. And we're certainly comfortable with the level we're at today that we could do that.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you look at prior election cycles, how do, I guess, transient and group react going into an election? Is it normal to see this type of pause?
componenttext: When you look at prior election cycles, how do, I guess, transient and group react going into an election? Is it normal to see this type of pause?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we've necessarily identified a trend. I mean, the 2 trends that we've seen is that sometimes a market like Washington will end up with a little bit softer business in the fourth quarter because when you're having a nationwide election, m
componenttext: I don't know that we've necessarily identified a trend. I mean, the 2 trends that we've seen is that sometimes a market like Washington will end up with a little bit softer business in the fourth quarter because when you're having a nationwide election, most of the elected officials tend to out of the city. And since that they draw for business in Washington, we've sometimes seen some softening of business in D.C. related to that. We have generally seen that the election week ends up being relatively slow on the group side because these larger groups are reluctant to schedule an event that would overlap Election Day. And so that's one of the reasons why we've indicated really for the last couple of quarters now, we've highlighted the fact that we were not overly confident about the fourth quarter. One reason is the holiday shift, but the other was the fact that we felt that this Election Day would be one that groups would be reluctant to book in. So I think what we're going to find when we get to the fourth quarter, not to get too far ahead of ourselves here, is that you're going to see some incredibly strong weeks because group is going to be very compacted into the sort of the open weeks of that quarter. And then those weeks that are affected either by the election or by the holiday will probably be fairly weak.

We're trying to take full advantage of it to offset the loss of business that we might otherwise have gotten if the convention center had been not under construction and fully available.

componenttextpreview: I'm not certain that I -- I think we're still going to end up finding that we have a weaker year in San Francisco, and the group bookings are going to probably -- the Marquis will probably be down for the full year. I just think that we do enough business
componenttext: I'm not certain that I -- I think we're still going to end up finding that we have a weaker year in San Francisco, and the group bookings are going to probably -- the Marquis will probably be down for the full year. I just think that we do enough business that's associated with the convention center that we have -- we do have a great meeting platform, but I don't know that it's big enough to completely replace all the citywide business. The one thing I would say though is that while a convention business will be off in San Francisco, we do think we have a very attractive hotel or hotels that are in great locations in that market. So we're going to have a -- it's going to be a struggle to overcome some of the weakness on the group side, but we're in good locations from a transient perspective, too.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I was just wondering if we could get a quick update on your outlook for supply. We talked a lot about 2016, maybe last quarter and before. But as you're looking out to '17, any shifts in some of your largest markets as we think about New York, San Fran
componenttext: So I was just wondering if we could get a quick update on your outlook for supply. We talked a lot about 2016, maybe last quarter and before. But as you're looking out to '17, any shifts in some of your largest markets as we think about New York, San Francisco, L.A., Boston and D.C.?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think in general, what we're -- the pattern that we've seen the last few years is that there's, of course, estimates from the experts in terms of what's going to happen with supply growth for the beginning of the year. And then normally, what seems
componenttext: Yes. I think in general, what we're -- the pattern that we've seen the last few years is that there's, of course, estimates from the experts in terms of what's going to happen with supply growth for the beginning of the year. And then normally, what seems to happen is by the time we get to this point in the year a little bit later, we begin to realize that the supply growth that's actually going to materialize is slightly less. It's because projects have a tendency to be delayed. And so this year, I think we started off the year thinking that nationwide supply was probably going to be just under 2, and now it feels like it might be more in that 1.6, 1.7 range, which is not a huge difference but still on the margin a little bit better. So that's sort of 16. We're expecting that supply next year will increase somewhat. I think we see that both in -- across the industry, and we also see that in the upper price points in the top 20 markets. So again, I'd say we're probably expecting the industry supply to be a little bit over 2 and probably expect that the supply in the top 20 markets is a little bit higher than that. I would also guess though that at some point, we're going to see -- we'll see the same sort of lengthening of the delivery time for that supply, which will hopefully maybe pull that down a little bit. New York continues -- New York and Houston and Miami tend to be the markets that continues to see the strongest supply. Seattle might be one more that falls into that category. We are seeing -- while supply for New York will continue to be robust and a lot of it is under construction, my sense in looking at the data was we were seeing fewer projects that were projected to start in the next 12 months and fewer projects in planning. And so we're hoping that, that may signal a return to some level of rationality around New York supply. But we're not going to see the benefits of that in 2017.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: I think it was right around that same level, maybe 7% or so higher. Now, again, as I've said in the past, this a little bit of an imprecise science, but I think in looking back at our comment to the prior quarter, we were probably -- we might have been just a hair higher in terms of Q1. And some of that would be reflective of the fact that the relationship between our -- the U.S. dollar and some of those other currencies is starting to lap over when we had an impact last year.
