Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc. Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Ms. Gee Lingberg. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. Before we begin, I'd like to remind everyone that many of the comments made today are considered to be forward-looking statements under federal
componenttext:
Thanks, Tony. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Host Hotels & Resorts Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. 
Before we begin, I'd like to remind everyone that many of the comments made today are considered to be forward-looking statements under federal securities laws. As described in our filings with the SEC, these statements are subject to numerous risks and uncertainties that could cause future results to differ from those expressed, and we are not obligated to publicly update or revise these forward-looking statements. 
In addition, on today's call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial information, such as FFO, adjusted EBITDA and comparable hotel results. You can find this information, together with reconciliations to the most directly comparable GAAP information, in today's earnings press release, in our 8-K filed with the SEC and the supplemental financial information on our website at hosthotels.com. 
With me on the call today is Ed Walter, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Greg Larson, our Chief Financial Officer. This morning, Ed will provide a brief overview of our operations and the company's outlook for 2016. Greg will then provide greater detail on our third quarter performance by markets and our balance sheet. Following their remarks, we will be available to respond to your questions. 
And now, I'd like to turn the call over to Ed.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Gee. Good morning, everyone. Overall, we had a solid quarter. Our operating results, given the trends the industry is experiencing, were quite good and in line with our expectations. We completed the sales of our last 2 New Zealand assets,
componenttext:
Well, thanks, Gee. Good morning, everyone. 
Overall, we had a solid quarter. Our operating results, given the trends the industry is experiencing, were quite good and in line with our expectations. We completed the sales of our last 2 New Zealand assets, continued to make progress on our redevelopment investments and repurchased 44 million of our stock in September, raising the year-to-date total returns to shareholders to over $800 million. 
Looking at our operating results. Adjusted EBITDA was $342 million for the quarter, reflecting an increase of 5.9%. Year-to-date, adjusted EBITDA was $1.123 billion, an increase of 5.3%. Our adjusted FFO was $0.37 per share for the third quarter and $1.28 year-to-date, reflecting an 11.3% increase over last year. Our strong EBITDA and FFO performance was driven by those top line growth and margin expansion. For the quarter, our average rate grew 2.2%, complemented by solid demand growth in our portfolio as comparable hotel occupancy grew by 1.2 percentage points, allowing our comparable hotel to achieve an occupancy rate of 81.3%. As a result, comparable RevPAR growth, on a constant dollar basis, increased 3.8%. The primary driver of our RevPAR growth this quarter was our group segment. Our domestic hotels benefited from a 3.4% increase in group demand, all generated by a significant increase in association demand. Corporate demand was uneven in the quarter, but the shift in the timing of the Jewish holiday from September of last year to October of this year led to a significant increase in corporate group during September. The net result was a 2.5% increase in average rate, which was generally achieved across all of our group segment, leading our domestic group revenues to increase by 6% for the quarter. Our international assets also [indiscernible] portfolio results in the quarter as our Canadian hotels benefited from strong transient demand, leading to RevPAR growth of almost 15%. And the Olympic Games generated 105% RevPAR growth in our Brazil assets. Since much of our Olympic business was booked this group, our overall group business actually increased by more than 9% for the quarter. As of the expected, the strength in group demand was partially offset by a decline in transient demand, which has been a scene for most of this calendar year. However, unlike the first 2 quarters, our hotels were able to increase rates and also push business into more highly rated segments, leading to transient rate growth of 2% for the quarter, taking into account the decline in transient demand, our transient revenue growth was slightly less than 1%. 
Recognizing the trends we have been experiencing this year, we have been focused on layering in more highly priced contract business at several of our hotels. A contract business, which is still only 5% of our total demand, increased nearly 15% for the quarter and is up 17% year-to-date. The one aspect of our operations that was disappointing in Q3 was our food and beverage department as food and beverage revenues increased by just 0.3%, which was roughly 2% less than we had anticipated. While F&B has been notoriously difficult to forecast, the bulk of the shortfall occurred in catering and resulted from group's being more conservative with their entertaining budget. [indiscernible] revenue actually grew by nearly 2%, which was an impressive result given that transient occupancy have decreased. Offsetting some of the weakness in F&B, our other department revenues grew by a strong 10.5%. We saw a strong increase in [indiscernible] revenues and an increase in attrition and cancellation fees, which was largely concentrated at 3 of our convention hotels. 
Comparable hotel revenues increased 3.3% for the quarter. The increase level of higher rated group activity, combined with the rate increase in our transient business as well as our continued focus on productivity improvements, resulted in strong rooms flow-through. This flow-through, plus reductions in utility and [indiscernible] expenses, contributed to our comparable EBITDA margin growth of 110 basis points in the third quarter. Year-to-date, comparable hotel RevPAR has increased 3% in constant currency terms. Food and beverage has improved by 2.1% and hotel revenues have increased by 3.1%. Comparable EBITDA margin growth is 90 basis points, which is generating 56% flow-through for the year, which is a very solid result. An important focus of our company is actively managing our portfolio and efficiently allocating capital. [indiscernible] goal, as I mentioned earlier, in the third quarter, we completed the sales of final 2 New Zealand properties for $31 million, bringing our year-to-date noncore asset sale total to approximately $500 million. We purchased this New Zealand portfolio for $190 million in New Zealand terms and received total sales proceeds in New Zealand dollars of 266 million, which allowed us to achieve better than a 14.5% unlevered IRR of this investment. We are currently marketing our remaining consolidated Asia-Pacific asset to [indiscernible] Hilton and we hope to complete to a sale during the first half of 2017. In addition, we are marketing a select few other noncore asset. While we are making reasonable progress on these sales, the transactions have not yet gone hard and we do not expect any additional asset sales will be completed in 2016. 
On the investment front, the company invested approximately $46 million in third quarter on redevelopment, return on investment and acquisition capital expenditures. We completed the initial phase of the Denver Marriott Tech Center redevelopment, which included newly-designed guest rooms in one of the towers, a new lobby and lounge, new fitness center and some additional meeting space. While we are pleased with the progress we have made on this project, we are slightly behind schedule due to some permitting challenges, but still expect to be completed by year-end. In addition, we have also made great progress on the first phase of the renovations at The Phoenician during the slower summer months. this phase included a completely design of the guestrooms, casinos and Canyon suites. We are excited to have an opportunity to show you our progress at The Phoenician before [indiscernible] in less than 2 weeks. 
For the full year, we expect to spend $200 million to $215 million on redevelopment, ROI and acquisition projects and $300 million and $310 million on renewal and replacement capital expenditures. 
Now let me spend a few minutes on our outlook for the remainder of 2016. Uncertainties surrounding the U.S. election and other international events lead us to believe that corporate profit growth and business investment levels will not improve meaningfully in the near term, suggesting that business transient demand will remain soft in the fourth quarter. While year-to-date, our domestic group revenues have been up nearly 4%, we expect to experience a softer fourth quarter as the Jewish holiday shift and nationwide election will reduce group demand as the traditionally lower occupancies in the fourth quarter will likely restrain rate growth. Our group booking and revenue pace for Q4 is only slightly positive and assuming continued short-term booking weakness, could easily be slightly negative for the fourth quarter. The combination of these factors suggest that we will experience minimal RevPAR growth in the fourth quarter, leading us to conclude that our full year comparable RevPAR will increase between 2% and 2.5%. 
Weaker group demand and negligible revenue growth will put pressure on operating margins in the fourth quarter, reversing to some degree, the strong results we have seen year-to-date. As a consequence, we expect our full year comparable hotel EBITDA margin growth improvement to be in the range of 40 to 55 basis points. This will translate to full year adjusted EBITDA of $1.440 billion to $1.455 billion and adjusted FFO per share of $1.64 to $1.66. 
Looking ahead to 2017. As we have indicated in prior years, our visibility at this time into next year is limited as we have just started on our detailed operating budget process. There are a number of factors that will influence operating results in 2017, starting, first and foremost, with the economy. This year, we are experiencing weaker GDP growth and declines in corporate profits and investments, plus the strength in the U.S. dollar. These factors have led to weak corporate transient demand and reduced international travel, resulting in industry demand growth of just 1.5%, which is well short of the average of nearly 3% for the last 3 years. The outlook for GDP, corporate profits and corporate investment is more favorable in 2017, but the concept that it will be better next year has been offered frequently during this recovery and generally hasn't come to fruition. The currency outlook is slightly more favorable, especially in countries such as Japan and Brazil, which could lead to better international travel trends. 
As opposed to the uncertainty surrounding demand factors, it is clear that supply is increasing. In our top 19 markets, upscaling [indiscernible] supplies increased by roughly 2.5% in 2016 while a number of reports have correctly noted that our portfolio is less exposed to new supplies than many others in the industry, primarily because we benefit from a more diversified distribution. Supply in our markets is still expected to increase by more than 3% in 2017. While we are experiencing record occupancies this year, this anticipated supply increase suggest that we will need to have stronger demand growth in 2017 to have pricing power. 
Our group revenues for 2017 are up over 2.5%, but short-term bookings have been growing at a slower rate and so we would not currently expect to benefit from the significant increase in group activity that we have seen in 2016. Combining all of these insights, along with the trend of weakening top line growth that we have seen over the last 2 years, we would not expect to see RevPAR accelerate in 2017 unless the economy improves meaningfully. We will provide much greater insight into our outlook for 2017 in our fourth quarter call in February. 
With that, let me turn the call over to Greg Larson, our Chief Financial Officer, who will discuss our operating and financial performance in more detail.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ed. I'll start with commentary on performance in several of our major markets. Our consolidated international hotel had a spectacular third quarter, with double-digit RevPAR increases in Latin America and Canada of more than 61% and almost 15
componenttext:
Thank you, Ed. I'll start with commentary on performance in several of our major markets. 
Our consolidated international hotel had a spectacular third quarter, with double-digit RevPAR increases in Latin America and Canada of more than 61% and almost 15%, respectively. As anticipated, the Olympics and Paralympic Games in Brazil drove significant increases in our 3 Brazilian hotels. Our hotels in Calgary and Toronto also experienced double-digit RevPAR growth. Toronto's outperformance was mainly the result of a Microsoft citywide in July, which caused compression in that market. Calgary experienced strong growth due to an increase in events at the Convention Center. Keep in mind that overall demand in Brazil, excluding the demands surrounding the Olympics, has been weak due to concerns over Zika, economic and political issues as well as increased supply. As a result, we expect [indiscernible] fundamentals in Brazil to weaken in the fourth quarter. 
As discussed last quarter, despite the slow start in San Diego in the first half of the year, RevPAR for assets in the market grew an impressive 11.8% this quarter, with occupancy growth of 5.6 percentage points and a 5% increase in average rate. Importantly, our RevPAR result exceeded the STAR upper upscale market results by 430 basis points. The increase in citywide room nights for NLB, All-Star game and [indiscernible] created healthy compression in the market and resulted in strong group business, which was up almost 26%. 
Looking to the fourth quarter. We expect our hotels in San Diego to continue to outperform our portfolio. Our hotels in Hawaii grew RevPAR 7.7% this quarter, leading the STAR upper upscale market results by 220 basis points. Occupancy increased 4.8 percentage points and average rate improved 2.1%. Strong transient demanded at our Maui hotels, coupled with solid group business at the Fairmont, [indiscernible] and Hyatt [indiscernible] Waikiki offset ballroom renovation displacement at Hyatt Maui. Short-term transient demand increased more than anticipated in August and September as vacationers chose Maui over the Zika feared Caribbean location and airfare cost remain stable. We expect our Hawaiian hotels to continue to outperform our portfolio in the fourth quarter. In addition, we should note that Hawaii is the market with the lowest expected supply growth out of the top 20 U.S. markets for the next couple of years, which bodes well for future performance. 
As expected, our properties in D.C. outperformed our portfolio again this quarter, with RevPAR growth of 6.8%, outpacing the STAR upper upscale market RevPAR increase by 120 basis points. This was driven predominantly by an average rate increase of 5.6% as well as a 90 basis point increase in occupancy. The Westin Georgetown, the AWDC and Grand Hyatt all had double-digit RevPAR growth this quarter, benefiting from renovations in the [indiscernible] and a strong group base that created [indiscernible] compression and enables the hotels to drive strong average rate growth. 
With elections next Tuesday and the resulting slowdown in legislative activity, we expect RevPAR growth to slow in the fourth quarter, but still expect outperformance relative to the portfolio. Even though we have not provided any guidance for 2017, it is worth mentioning that citywide's in 2017 look strong for D.C. Combined with Congress operating on a full calendar and inauguration in January, we expect there will be additional demand in 2017. 
Los Angeles continues to outperform the portfolio, with a 6.6% increase in the third quarter. The results were driven by a 3.5% growth in average rate and a 2.5 percentage point increase in occupancy. Strong group in contract business at several of our hotels drove the RevPAR increase, which exceeded the STAR upper upscale market results by 120 basis points. Year-to-date, our hotels in Los Angeles have grown RevPAR by 8.9%. Looking forward to the fourth quarter, group bookings [indiscernible] in Los Angeles remains strong and as a result, we expect continued outperformance from our Los Angeles properties. 
In Atlanta, RevPAR increased 5.6% for the quarter as a result of average rate growth of 0.8% and occupancy increase of 3.6 percentage points. Continued strong citywide group room nights in the third quarter contributed to the outperformance. As anticipated, the citywide calendar on a year-over-year basis for the fourth quarter will be weak. Therefore, we expect fourth quarter RevPAR to be flat to last year. 
Moving to some challenged markets. New York RevPAR decreased 4%, basically in line with the STAR upper upscale decline of 3.6%. Supply continues to outpace demand, which, when combined with lower European travel and tour business due to strong and lower European travel and tour business due to strong U.S. dollar, continued to significantly impact our ability to drive rates. Based on our outlook for the market, we expect the hotels in New York to continue to have a RevPAR decline in the fourth quarter. 
RevPAR in the San Francisco hotels decline 3.4%, with a decrease in both occupancy and rate this quarter. Group room nights were down due to the Moscone Convention Center expansion, which will continue to negatively impact San Francisco in 2017. Due to the lack of group compression, almost all hotels put more lower rate in transient business, resulting in overall transient ADR decline of 5.4%. Our San Francisco hotels will likely underperform our portfolio in the fourth quarter. 
The Houston market continues to be impacted by the struggling oil industry and increased supply, as evidenced by the severe declines in the STAR upper upscale of nearly 14%. Our Houston hotels RevPAR declined 2.9% in the quarter and a 3.7% decrease in ADR was partially offset by a small increase in occupancy. Two major citywide events did not repeat in the third quarter this year, compelling our managers to put group business at our hotels to maintain occupancy. This proved to be the right strategy as we beat the STAR upper upscale market by 11 percentage points. We expect the difficulties in Houston to continue in the fourth quarter, and therefore, anticipate that these hotels will underperform the portfolio. 
RevPAR in the hotels in Seattle declined 1.5% in the third quarter. Occupancy declined about 1 percentage point to almost 91% and ADR decreased 0.3%. Last year, our hotels in Seattle had a record group business in the quarter and grew RevPAR 9.8%, making for difficult comparisons this year. Many of the groups in the third quarter last year did not repeat this year and the market has seen a decrease in Canadian [indiscernible] business, contributing to the weaker results this quarter. We expect performance to improve in the fourth quarter as transient demand increases and the [indiscernible] Seattle will benefit from being under renovation last December. 
RevPAR to Phoenix hotels grew 0.6% in the quarter, with an occupancy decline of 4.3 percentage points and an increase in ADR of 7.9%. Our hotels were negatively impacted by group cancellation, [indiscernible] and soft transient demand. We expect RevPAR to hotels in Phoenix to improve in the fourth quarter. 
Shifting to our European joint venture. The portfolio continued to be negatively impacted by a number of macro factors, including. The lingering effects of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, and the political and economic uncertainty pre-and post Brexit. All this led to a RevPAR decline of 2.6% in constant euros this quarter. As expected, our hotels in Paris and Brussels significantly underperformed the portfolio while our hotels in London, Spain and Stockholm outperformed. We expect our hotels in Paris and Brussels will continue to be challenged in the fourth quarter. 
As noted in our press release, during the third quarter, we repurchased 2.8 million shares in an average purchase price of $16.04 or a total purchase price of $44 million. Since the inception of our share repurchase program in April of 2015, we have bought back 51.4 million shares of common stock for a total purchase price of approximately $883 million. We currently have $117 million of capacity remaining under the repurchase program. In addition, in October, we paid a regular third quarter cash dividend of $0.20 per share, which represents an annualized yield of over 5% on the current stock price. Based on current operating forecast, combined with taxable gains generated from our completed asset sales to date and our regular fourth quarter dividend, we expect to pay a special dividend of approximately $0.05, bringing total dividends for the fourth quarter to $0.25 per share. We continued to operate from a position of financial strength and flexibility and believe we have one of the best balance sheets in the lodging REIT and overall REIT space. Importantly, we view this as a key competitive and strategic advantage, which enhances our ability to pay our dividends throughout the cycle and allows us to invest as opportunities arise to buy asset, buy back our stock or reinvest in high yielding, redevelopment or ROI projects. 
We ended the third quarter with approximately $340 million of cash and currently have $628 million of available capacity under our revolving credit facility. We improved our leverage ratio as calculated under our credit facility to 2.5x. It is important to note that when updating models for 2017, our 2016 adjusted EBITDA includes $12 million for the reimbursement of operating losses at the New Orleans Marriott due to the 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill. In addition, the 2016 full year guidance includes adjusted EBITDA of $13 million that was earned by the hotels that have been sold during the year. Therefore, a total of $25 million of EBITDA will not repeat in 2017. However, keep in mind that comparable EBITDA margin growth in 2016 was not impacted by these items as the business interruption insurance proceeds and sold assets are excluded from our comparable hotel results. 
In summary, we are pleased with our results this quarter as the profitability of our assets continues to improve due to our aggressive asset management strategy in what continues to be a competitive environment. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. We are now interested in answering any questions you may have. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I believe you mentioned group cancellations a few times in your script, so if you could give us some more details on the what exactly was going on there? And what markets were impacted? And if you expect that to continue next year?
componenttext: I believe you mentioned group cancellations a few times in your script, so if you could give us some more details on the what exactly was going on there? And what markets were impacted? And if you expect that to continue next year?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Overall, we've seen that cancellation and attrition fees, which is what we were talking about, has been higher this year than they have been the last few years. Now I would tell you that the level of attrition cancellations we saw in the first half o
componenttext: Yes. Overall, we've seen that cancellation and attrition fees, which is what we were talking about, has been higher this year than they have been the last few years. Now I would tell you that the level of attrition cancellations we saw in the first half of this decade was below what I would describe as our long-term average. But the bottom line is, is they're up about 30% for the year. They were up closer to about 60% this particular quarter. We saw the cancellations in Orlando and at 2 of our larger convention hotels, one in San Francisco, which I suspect might have been a little bit related to some of the activity out there at the Convention Center that you all are fully aware of and also at the Marquis. I would imagine that we think that will moderate a bit in the fourth quarter, but it's not abnormal despite of the cycle to start to see a little bit more in terms of cancellation and attrition activity. So we would expect to see that continue at a slightly elevated level compared to that 2010 to 2015 time frame. Part of that, I would note though, is I'd be careful to draw the conclusions that means that people are canceling or not showing up to a greater degree in the past. I'm sure that's part of what's happening. Some of that, this is also reflective of the fact that we have better contracts from our perspective, which is enabling us to recover more when folks don't show up.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Greg, I think you mentioned your ability to pay your dividend through the cycle. What did you mean by that? And are you committed to maintaining your current dividend even if taxable income goes down a bit next year?
componenttext: And Greg, I think you mentioned your ability to pay your dividend through the cycle. What did you mean by that? And are you committed to maintaining your current dividend even if taxable income goes down a bit next year?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, obviously, as I noted today, our taxable income actually exceeds the $0.80. And so yes, I think what we've said in the past is that we would like to pay our dividend throughout this next cycle and if our taxable income were to have a modest d
componenttext: Yes. I mean, obviously, as I noted today, our taxable income actually exceeds the $0.80. And so yes, I think what we've said in the past is that we would like to pay our dividend throughout this next cycle and if our taxable income were to have a modest drop next year, yes, I think because we have one of the best balance sheets in the entire REIT universe, I think we're in a good position to be able to continue to pay the dividend.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Again, when we look at our hotels in Latin America, I mean, they had a RevPAR increase north of 60%. So obviously...

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One way to look at that, Joe, would be, I think, for the full year, we're probably expecting that our Brazil hotels will generate between, call it, $10 million to $12 million worth of EBITDA. So they're not overly significant to our overall results,
componenttext: Yes. One way to look at that, Joe, would be, I think, for the full year, we're probably expecting that our Brazil hotels will generate between, call it, $10 million to $12 million worth of EBITDA. So they're not overly significant to our overall results, but there was -- we had an incredibly strong quarter, especially at the top line. And that obviously did influence our overall results for the quarter. Having said that, if you look at our domestic results, we still had a very solid quarter from a domestic perspective, with RevPAR being up 2.8%. So no doubt that, that headline number is better because of Brazil, but we were strong in Mexico and we were strong in Toronto, too. So all of our international hotels had a good quarter and domestic portfolio did, too.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then you talked about this in your earlier prepared remarks about the transaction market, but can you talk about the asset sale transaction market? I guess, how frozen is it now? Especially when you look at markets with high supply growth, say,
componenttext: Great. And then you talked about this in your earlier prepared remarks about the transaction market, but can you talk about the asset sale transaction market? I guess, how frozen is it now? Especially when you look at markets with high supply growth, say, a city like New York.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I would say that it's certainly not -- I think you've heard this from others, the market's not as robust as it was in '14 and the first half of '15. Having said that, I would say that there's still activity happening. I just think deals take longer.
componenttext: Yes. I would say that it's certainly not -- I think you've heard this from others, the market's not as robust as it was in '14 and the first half of '15. Having said that, I would say that there's still activity happening. I just think deals take longer. The number of folks that are participating in a particular or chasing a particular transaction is probably a little bit thinner. We're hearing that as we talk with the brokerage community, as we look at the experience we're having, we're finding that international buyers are probably a bit higher percentage of the activity than in past. You're seeing some slower operators associated with family offices, chase after some of the smaller deals that are after. I was also -- I've heard that some of the non-public, nontraded or nonlisted REITs have been a bit more active, too. So there's still a market out there. I think we're still -- I'm still reasonably optimistic that we're -- I certainly feel optimistic we'll sell Melbourne. I think there is a decent chance that we'll complete a few more asset sales. I started off in saying the market is not as strong as it had been and that's why you're not seeing as many sales announced by folks.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Shaun Kelley of Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll go next to Shaun Kelley of Bank of America.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ed, maybe just a follow-up on that last point. You had laid out a sort of a program of I think $500 million to $1 billion. You're sort of at the lower bound of that now of what you wanted to target. Is there a chance that I guess getting further reaching
componenttext: Ed, maybe just a follow-up on that last point. You had laid out a sort of a program of I think $500 million to $1 billion. You're sort of at the lower bound of that now of what you wanted to target. Is there a chance that I guess getting further reaching too much further closer to the $1 billion is increasingly off the table just given what you're seeing out there. How are you thinking about that target now?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I -- short answer is, is that I think we can still, over the next 3 quarters, get to the $1 billion number. But we're -- I would also say that, that is totally dependent on us feeling comfortable with the pricing that we get. As Greg talked about the stre
componenttext: I -- short answer is, is that I think we can still, over the next 3 quarters, get to the $1 billion number. But we're -- I would also say that, that is totally dependent on us feeling comfortable with the pricing that we get. As Greg talked about the strength of our balance sheet, I think you all recognize that. We're not doing this for liquidity reasons. We're doing this because we're trying to be smart on how to continue to position our portfolio for the future. And the assets that we're selling now are just ones that we generally think will not perform as well as the remainder of our portfolio or may have higher capital needs. One exception to that will be Melbourne where we've made the conscious decision to exit the Asia-Pacific market. And so we want to sell that property. We won't sell that for a bad price by any means, but that is one that we are more motivated to sell perhaps and some others. So bottom line is, is that I think we still have a reasonable shot at getting to the high end of that range, but we'll be thoughtful in terms of evaluating the sale opportunities that we have and making the decisions going forward on those sales.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. I appreciate that. And then, my follow-up is -- relates to some of your comments on supply. So appreciate that color as we look forward to next year. If I recapped, I think you guys said that in host markets, you're looking for greater than 3% supp
componenttext: Great. I appreciate that. And then, my follow-up is -- relates to some of your comments on supply. So appreciate that color as we look forward to next year. If I recapped, I think you guys said that in host markets, you're looking for greater than 3% supply in 2017. Can you just give us a sense of where is that number this year in host markets? So kind of we can kind of compare and see how big of an acceleration you're anticipating?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you mean what is it -- I'm sorry, what is that number this year, is that what you were asking?
componenttext: Well, you mean what is it -- I'm sorry, what is that number this year, is that what you were asking?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, correct. Correct.
componenttext: Yes, correct. Correct.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the number that we're quoting, what we're finding today is relevant, is to look at upscale and above. Well, I think you know that upper upscale segment generally has very light supply, and I think that's coming -- it's still coming in general
componenttext: Yes, I think the number that we're quoting, what we're finding today is relevant, is to look at upscale and above. Well, I think you know that upper upscale segment generally has very light supply, and I think that's coming -- it's still coming in generally across-the-board in our markets at less than 2%. But it's clear to us that depending upon the property, you may compete with upscale supply, too. And so as we look at that particular number, this year, we would say that across our top 19 or 20 markets, we're looking at supply that's roughly 2.5% in 2016. We think that's going to escalate to slightly more than 3% in 2017. Markets that we're a bit concerned about would be [indiscernible], Seattle, Denver, Houston and New York. I think a thing of note for us though is that we do have -- well, while those markets represent about, call it, 15% of our EBITDA, if you -- we also have great representation in some markets that are, like Atlanta, Hawaii, San Diego or San Francisco that are expected to have much lower supply and in fact, those last 4 markets that I just referred to, we have more than 25% of our EBITDA coming from those markets. So hence, my point in our prepared remarks that when we look -- when we see our portfolio compared to others, we think we have a little bit less exposure to supply than some others because of the diversity in the portfolio.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: Yes, we had agreed, at least for the short term, not provide specifics about that, that particular transaction. So unfortunately, I'm going to have to abide by that agreement. But I would say that, what we -- we had an opportunity there where a contract was expiring and there was a chance to [indiscernible] our management fees. We extended the term a bit but we retained a fair amount of flexibility in terms of how the hotel would be operating going forward.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you look across our portfolio, we had -- we do continue to have a number of opportunities. It probably falls in the realm of a couple of years as you sort of space things out over the next 5 to 7 years, where there was an opportunity to consider eithe
componenttext: And you look across our portfolio, we had -- we do continue to have a number of opportunities. It probably falls in the realm of a couple of years as you sort of space things out over the next 5 to 7 years, where there was an opportunity to consider either replacing the existing branded operator with the franchise operator or we may have contracts to terminate [indiscernible] even more flexibility. So I think it's an area that we've been able to have a fair amount of -- we do -- where we've made [indiscernible] conversions or where we've changed contracts. We're consistently seeing anywhere from a 10% to 20% in EBITDA as a result of the changes that we're making and it's something that we just build into our business plan for each year is to look at the opportunities that may exist for that year, and then try to exploit them.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, just as a follow-up. With the closing of the Marriott Starwood transaction, can you just give any kind of initial color on the potential impact there? And any difference in hotel level fundamentals between the two companies in comparable change?
componenttext: And then, just as a follow-up. With the closing of the Marriott Starwood transaction, can you just give any kind of initial color on the potential impact there? And any difference in hotel level fundamentals between the two companies in comparable change?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of course, at this point, Dave, they've only been closed for probably less than 45 days and certainly, may be the biggest issue that surrounds that whole transaction from our perspective as an owner will be how smoothly and how successfully the integratio
componenttext: Of course, at this point, Dave, they've only been closed for probably less than 45 days and certainly, may be the biggest issue that surrounds that whole transaction from our perspective as an owner will be how smoothly and how successfully the integration goes. I'm sure that Marriott and Arnie will give you more insights into those issues on their call, which I'm assuming is later this week. I guess, what I'd say, as we looked at this and that we've consistently said that since the transaction was announced, if our Starwood hotels were operated under the Marriott expense and cost structure, not fee structure but the operating costs of running those hotels, we think that there would be an opportunity to reduce expenses at our Starwood hotels. There's a number of elements of Marriott system [indiscernible] reservations or purchasing, or some other areas, including their agreements with the online company where the Marriott contracts and Marriott cost structure is cheaper. I can't --  know that as they work their way through the integration process, we will start to see the benefits of those cost savings, but it's a little hard right now for us to predict how quickly that will happen.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Thomas Allen with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: We'll go next to Thomas Allen with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It seems like one of the bright spots during the [indiscernible] season has been leisure trends outperforming. I mean, how long do you think that later trends can continue to outperform given the corporate environment? And any other thoughts on leisure tr
componenttext: It seems like one of the bright spots during the [indiscernible] season has been leisure trends outperforming. I mean, how long do you think that later trends can continue to outperform given the corporate environment? And any other thoughts on leisure trends will be helpful.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as long as employment remains fairly strong, then I would say, looking back in past history, leisure should probably hold up fairly well. If you go back to the 2001 to 2003 downturn, we generally found throughout that downturn, because it was not
componenttext: I think as long as employment remains fairly strong, then I would say, looking back in past history, leisure should probably hold up fairly well. If you go back to the 2001 to 2003 downturn, we generally found throughout that downturn, because it was not from an economic perspective, it was not that severe, and unemployment, if my recollection serves me right, did not increase significantly during that time period, we found that our resort hotels outperformed during that time period and we generally found that leisure travel was fairly strong. I think going forward, the other thing that will affect leisure travel, the international leisure, we've had -- the 18 months have been a bit weak primarily because of currency. But assuming that the currency stabilizes, I think there's an opportunity for some pick up there. We're generally fairly bullish as we look out over the next 5 years about our resort profile. We think it benefits from both the combination of the leisure trends that we just discussed and secondarily, it benefits from the fact that supply in the resort segment is much lower than the industry as a whole.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then can you just give us an update on how you think the hotel [indiscernible] direct booking push is affecting your business?
componenttext: And then can you just give us an update on how you think the hotel [indiscernible] direct booking push is affecting your business?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're generally in favor of what they're trying to do there. We know that there is some short-term pain associated with that. It's -- the best estimate that I have heard of that is it might have cost us a couple of 10s of RevPAR growth in the last couple
componenttext: We're generally in favor of what they're trying to do there. We know that there is some short-term pain associated with that. It's -- the best estimate that I have heard of that is it might have cost us a couple of 10s of RevPAR growth in the last couple of quarters. So we're watching it and we will, obviously, to the extent that it doesn't seem to be accomplishing their goals, may urge them to reconsider. But at this point in time, we feel comfortable with heading down that path. I mean, the bottom line is the reservation made through an operator website is a heck of a lot cheaper for us than one that might come through an OTA in terms of cost associated with that booking. And so to the extent that we can drive more traffic to that operator website, we generally think that it makes a difference for us on the bottom line and that's what matters most to us.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Smedes Rose with Citi.
componenttext: We'll go next to Smedes Rose with Citi.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering if you could maybe talk about, and I'm sure you'll give more detail on your fourth quarter call, but just kind of your CapEx priorities as you think about '17 and where you are? You have about $100 million left on your share repurchas
componenttext: I was just wondering if you could maybe talk about, and I'm sure you'll give more detail on your fourth quarter call, but just kind of your CapEx priorities as you think about '17 and where you are? You have about $100 million left on your share repurchase program, would you look to continue to buy back shares at these levels? Or just sort of general thoughts around that?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me answer the second question first. We will be buying more of our shares back, especially if the price remains at the current level, and we do -- we have a balance sheet capability to do that. We have the authorization from the board to do that
componenttext: Sure. Let me answer the second question first. We will be buying more of our shares back, especially if the price remains at the current level, and we do -- we have a balance sheet capability to do that. We have the authorization from the board to do that. So you should assume that we'll continue to pursue a share buyback. CapEx for next year, I'd say, we've been targeting for a few years now to be spending a bit less, especially on maintenance CapEx in '16 and I think that will carry over in '17. So I would generally expect to see a little bit less capital in '17. Our thought had generally been that we would prefer to -- we would look to increase capital spending a bit later in the cycle under the period that it cost us a little bit maybe less in terms of lost occupancy and it cost us a little bit less because oftentimes, as you get near the end of the cycle, pricing for construction projects drops too. So we're not at the point we're making any decisions about '18. We are looking hard at our '17 plan, and I'd say, general -- the general initial sense, without putting a hard number on it, it will be lower than what we'd spend in '16.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. You mentioned earlier, too, that just all things being equal, that Marriott hotels run at a, I guess, higher relative operating margin versus Starwood. And I'm just wondering, just 2 similar hotels side-by-side, like what is kind of
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. You mentioned earlier, too, that just all things being equal, that Marriott hotels run at a, I guess, higher relative operating margin versus Starwood. And I'm just wondering, just 2 similar hotels side-by-side, like what is kind of the difference, all things being equal? Is it like 50 basis points or is it 1 point of margin or just kind of very broadly?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Smedes, I know that it is less, but I'm not confident enough sitting here right now to give you a direct answer on that question. So I don't think it's more than 1 point, let's put it that way.
componenttext: Smedes, I know that it is less, but I'm not confident enough sitting here right now to give you a direct answer on that question. So I don't think it's more than 1 point, let's put it that way.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Dave Loeb with Baird.
componenttext: We'll go next to Dave Loeb with Baird.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wonder if I could just take you back to capital allocation. I noted the increased ROE spending in the fourth quarter and I wonder if you could just comment about how you look at ROE spending versus buybacks? And how tightly tied are future asset sales a
componenttext: I wonder if I could just take you back to capital allocation. I noted the increased ROE spending in the fourth quarter and I wonder if you could just comment about how you look at ROE spending versus buybacks? And how tightly tied are future asset sales and [indiscernible] stock buybacks?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The -- I would say that the increase that you saw in the ROI with the redevelopment CapEx is a lot more to just do with the timing of when we expect to complete projects and probably the more so when we expect to close them out, rather than being an indic
componenttext: The -- I would say that the increase that you saw in the ROI with the redevelopment CapEx is a lot more to just do with the timing of when we expect to complete projects and probably the more so when we expect to close them out, rather than being an indication of any change in philosophy or change in quantity in terms of our projects. There maybe a little bit of a couple of projects being a hair more expensive than what we hit originally anticipated, but the reality is, overall talking with our construction group, our overall budget -- our overall performance of where the budget is coming in pretty consistently with what we expected. And so that mile increase that you see in the numbers compared to the prior quarter really just reflects the fact that we expected to pay [indiscernible] across this year and that's likely because of finishing a little bit sooner with some of those projects. I think as -- looking beyond that and thinking more broadly, we look at all of these different options, whether it's investing in the portfolio, buying stock or other investments. It's kind of a comparative basis. Opportunities do enhance the portfolio of generally driven higher rates, higher levels of returns will continue to be an attractive. Having said that, I don't think we have as many of those opportunities in '17 as we've had in '15 and '16 and so I expect the volume of activity in there will be lower.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll go next to Rich Hightower with Evercore ISI.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just another twist on the Marriott Starwood question. So I appreciate the color that you guys were able to give on in terms of how you're looking at '17 at this point. But to the extent that Marriott is able to give an initial look on '17 RevPAR, when
componenttext: So just another twist on the Marriott Starwood question. So I appreciate the color that you guys were able to give on in terms of how you're looking at '17 at this point. But to the extent that Marriott is able to give an initial look on '17 RevPAR, when it reports next week, and also given that the, I believe, that the overlap in terms of concentration within Host portfolio is even higher today, now that the deal is closing [indiscernible] before, do you think that there would be any material differences in how they view North American RevPAR growth next year versus what you guys might think about your portfolio?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a great question, and I think, to some degree, we're all sort of chuckling here as we hear that. Here's what I would tell you. Clearly, our hotels and the position they're in, both physically and locationally, should generally perform in line
componenttext: Yes, that's a great question, and I think, to some degree, we're all sort of chuckling here as we hear that. Here's what I would tell you. Clearly, our hotels and the position they're in, both physically and locationally, should generally perform in line with what Marriott was generally suggesting their sort of broad-based brands would deliver. Now they're added to -- their optimism about what the numbers might be for next year versus our trying to be realistic good -- it's hard to predict exactly how they're going to look at next year and what message they want to try to convey. So I guess, at the end of the day, we've tried to provide you with as clear a view as we can have at this particular time in terms of what's going to happen for '17. Ultimately, as you're suggesting, I would expect our hotels would generally perform in line with what they would be predicting for domestic performance because our hotels represent a big part of their portfolio.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I agree with that. I mean, obviously, there are some geographic differences as well. And for us, as you know, Rich, a lot of the supply growth recently has been on the [indiscernible] service side. And they have, obviously, quite a bit of select serv
componenttext: Yes, I agree with that. I mean, obviously, there are some geographic differences as well. And for us, as you know, Rich, a lot of the supply growth recently has been on the [indiscernible] service side. And they have, obviously, quite a bit of select service. We do not, so that could be another difference as well.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's very hopeful, guys. And my second question is just on G&A. As you think about the fact that you're exiting certain markets around the country and around the world as well, I'm assuming that transaction expenses are included in the corporate G&
componenttext: Yes, that's very hopeful, guys. And my second question is just on G&A. As you think about the fact that you're exiting certain markets around the country and around the world as well, I'm assuming that transaction expenses are included in the corporate G&A line item at this point. I didn't see a different number anywhere else in the release. Do you see G&A savings opportunities in some of those categories or other categories as we kind of think about next year and beyond?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that I would -- the short answer is yes, in the standpoint that as we have phased out of the Asian market, we are certainly cutting expenses in that market and so that there is some benefit that flows from that. I don't know that I would nece
componenttext: I don't know that I would -- the short answer is yes, in the standpoint that as we have phased out of the Asian market, we are certainly cutting expenses in that market and so that there is some benefit that flows from that. I don't know that I would necessarily expect [indiscernible] modeling our G&A expense but you should be thinking that there'd be radical differences from one year to the next in the context of '16, looking at '17.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016

componenttext: We'll go next to Robin Farley with UBS.

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think in the past, you've talked about leaving RevPAR to grow in the 2%, 3% range to kind of offset increases in expense. And your comments about next year kind of suggest that you may be you wouldn't expect more than a 2% increase, maybe even lower or
componenttext: I think in the past, you've talked about leaving RevPAR to grow in the 2%, 3% range to kind of offset increases in expense. And your comments about next year kind of suggest that you may be you wouldn't expect more than a 2% increase, maybe even lower or just kind of something similar to this year's levels, around 2%. How should we think about expense growth without -- or I guess impact on profitability if RevPAR is not up above the level to offset those higher expenses? And your comment about maybe savings from the Starwood Marriott transaction. If I'm understanding that right, it sounded like maybe that's only 100 basis points of expense to be offset. And I guess, that would only be in the sort of -- I don't know, is that like 20%, 25% of your [indiscernible] that are Starwood -- coming from Starwood, maybe you could put some color around that?

headline: Host Hotels & Resorts, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Sure. So I guess first off, I would say that in terms of thinking about the level of RevPAR and revenue growth that we likely would need from one year to the next in order to maintain the margins that we have, I say today, our thinking is that needs
componenttext: Sure. Sure. So I guess first off, I would say that in terms of thinking about the level of RevPAR and revenue growth that we likely would need from one year to the next in order to maintain the margins that we have, I say today, our thinking is that needs to be right around or just slightly above 2%. And that's based on nothing more complicated than expecting inflation to generally run at about that level. And so if our cost go up by inflations and we sort of need to match that at the revenue line in order to maintain our margins. I will point out that does not -- that does mean that EBITDA grows at that same rate of inflation or slightly better. And so that's not suggesting that we'd be a slight EBITDA. But I think that's still a reasonable reference point. We do think that there are some things that we're working on now, including a continuation of the time motion study work that we've done, which we've talked about before [indiscernible] fair amount of money this year. We do think there are some things on those lines that might benefit us next year and, of course, to the extent that we end up with the lower level of RevPAR growth that we've been suggesting, that we'll be working hard to try to find other ways to take costs out. Some of that will, of course, be dependent upon whether that lower level of RevPAR is generated more by a lack of rate growth or perhaps a reduction in occupancy. The latter, obviously, gives us a better opportunity to try and take cost out of the system. In terms of the benefits that would flow from the Marriott Starwood merger, I honestly would not be expecting to see a significant amount of that benefit in 2017. There are a few things that could happen more quickly, I believe, but I think there's still some work to be done [indiscernible]. I believe that the opportunity to benefit from some -- the new Marriott negotiated OTA agreement could probably take hold next year. But I think longer, a lot of the other integration activities that would be required for us to get the expense savings [indiscernible] happen and so I will not be counting on the benefit of that in 2017.

In other words, would you, haven't been a buyer of assets, but would it make sense, could it make sense to [indiscernible] with consolidation among kind of small or medium-sized REITs?

I think we should end it. We apologize for what seems to be a technical difficulty here, but the team will be available to answer any of your questions throughout the rest of the day and tomorrow. 
Thank you for joining us on this call today. We appreciate the opportunity to talk about our third quarter. We look forward to seeing many of you at the [indiscernible] in Phoenix in a couple of weeks and, of course, talking to you in February to discuss both our year-end 2016 results and provide a lot more insight into 2017. Have a great day. Thank you.
